info.title: Advanced analog and RF integrated circuits design I
info.prerequisite_for: Semester projects and master thesis projects in micro- et nanoelectronics
info.content:
1) Background : Review of fundamental passive and active integrated components and their models.

2) Noise Analysis and Modeling : noise characterization; thermal noise; flicker noise; other types of noise; noise models of circuit elements; noise analysis in circuits; examples: single-stage OTA.

3) Fundamentals of Filter Design : types of filters; frequency and impedance normalization; filter specifications; approximation; passive synthesis; second-order sections - the biquads; high-order filter design; non-ideal effects.

4) Integrated Active Filters Implementations : continuous-time filters: RC-active, Gm-C filters, MOSFET-C filters; switched-capacitor filters: basic building blocks, basic operation and analysis, first-order filter, biquad filters; high-order filters: component simulation of LC ladders, operational simulation of LC ladders; non-ideal effects.
info.learning_outcomes:
This course covers the analysis and design of advanced analog integrated circuits, focusing on the design of integrated filters. It starts reviewing the passive and active devices and looks at the fundamental limitations such as noise and distortion. It then presents the different implementations of integrated filters including switched-capacitor and continuous-time techniques.
The main objective is to be able to design analog integrated filters starting from the system specifications and choosing the appropriate technique.

title: Advanced analog and RF integrated circuits design I

info.title: Advanced analog and RF integrated circuits design II
info.prerequisite_for: Semester projects and master thesis projects in micro et nanoelectronics

1) Background : overview of wireless principles.

2) Modeling of Active and Passive Devices at RF : MOS and bipolar transistors; integrated R L C components.

3) Noise at RF : classical noisy two-port theory; examples of noise calculations in RF circuits.

4) Distortion and Intermodulation : origin of distortion; characterization of distortion at RF; intermodulation, intercept points.

5) Basic Receiver Architectures : super-heterodyne; low-IF; direct conversion; super-regenerative.

6) Front-end circuits : low-noise amplifier (LNA) design; mixers.

7) Oscillators : basic tuned oscillators (Colpitts, Pierce, Clapp, cross-coupled); phase-noise.

8) Frequency Synthesizers : basic frequency synthesizers.

9) RF Power Amplifiers : class A, AB, B, and C power amplifiers; class D, E and F amplifiers.

It starts with a review of active and passive devices operation and modelling at RF. The fundamental limitations such as noise and distortion are discussed in the perspective of radio transceivers. The main transceiver architectures are presented and the most important building blocks are discussed.
The main objective is to understand RF transceivers and be able to design basic RF integrated circuits.

info.learning_outcomes: The Internet has changed the way people perceive computers, communicate and do business. A key component of many successful Internet applications is a scalable, high-performance, and highly-available distributed system. Moreover, as the planetary-scale services become prevalent and grow in importance, it becomes necessary to understand the distributed systems underpinnings that will enable the future applications. This is a distributed systems course with an experimental systems viewpoint: the course will discuss the architecture and teach the understanding of the performance of real systems. The title of the course reflects the blurring of boundaries between computer networks and distributed systems, as often distributed systems are used to implement large-scale services that could not be implemented and deployed solely at the network level. The syllabus for this research-oriented course is driven by published, current papers. After completing the course, the students should be able to engage in doctoral-level research in this field. Paper evaluations that demand critical reasoning will be a part of the grade. There will be a midterm and a final group project report, with a goal of publishing the best projects in top conferences (with additional work).

info.title: Advanced multiprocessor architecture
info.exam_form_detail: A mid-term and a final exam.
info.content:
Introduction to multiprocessor systems, parallel programming models including Pthreads, MPI, hardware and software transactional memory, synchronization primitives, memory consistency mdels, cache coherence, on-chip shared cache architectures, on-chip interconnects, multi-chip interconnects, multi-chip bus-based and general-purpose interconnect-based shared-memory systems, clusters.
The course will include weekly readings, discussions, and student reviews and reports on publications (besides the text book) of seminal and recent contributions to the field of computer architecture. Student reviews, class discussions, and an independent research project will account for a significant fraction of the grade. Feedback on performance will be given only upon request by a student. There will be no recitation classes.
The course will also include an independent and original research project, in which students study, improve, and evaluate multiprocessor innovations using a software simulation infrastructure. There will be a list of project ideas given out, but students can suggest and work on their own ideas with potentials for advancing the state of the art.
info.prior_knowledge: Computer Architecture I & II (Processor Architecture Lab), basic C/C++ systems programming.
info.learning_outcomes: Increasing levels of integration in semiconductor fabrication processes along with unprecedented levels of power consumption in large-window wide-issue single-core processors is forcing computer architects to organize transistors into multiple processing cores on a single chip. While parallel computers have only held a niche market until now mostly in the server and supercomputer domains, this disruptive shift in architecture will result in parallel architectures becoming mainstream in all products from embedded computers all the way to supercomputers. This course covers the fundamentals of multiprocessor computer architecture -- i.e., computer systems built from individual processing elements while balancing performance, cost, and programmability. The course qualitatively and quantitatively examines multiprocessor design trade-offs. We will study, for example, parallel programming models, multithreaded processors, chip multiprocesssors, symmetric multiprocessors, distributed shared memory, and scalable clusters. The goal is to educate the student in the history and future trends of multiprocessor computer architecture.

info.learning_outcomes:

2. Get more familiar with the latest discoveries in the world of nanotechnology research.

info.title: Advanced signal processing
info.prerequisite_for: Semester projects, master thesis projects and doctoral thesis
info.content:
Recal
Fourier Transform, sampling, Z transform, digital signal processing

Digital filter design
Fourier, Z, filtering and filters. Design of finite impulse response filters by using windows or by frequency sampling. Design of infinite impulse response filters by analog-digital transformation, in particular bilinear transformation. Filter banks.

Spectral analysis
Motivation of spectral analysis. Notions of statistical estimation (probability distribution, bias, variance, confidence interval). Non-parametric spectral analysis (periodogram, smoothed and averaged periodogram). Comparison between the different methods.

Elements of time-frequency analysis
Motivation of time-frequency analysis. Fourier analysis. The uncertainty principle. Time-frequency ditributions. Gabor transform, continuous wavelet transform. Instantaneous frequency and estimation algorithms. Time-scale analysis.
info.learning_outcomes: This course is devoted to advanced techniques in signal processing. At the end of this course, the students will be able to apply methods such as filter design and filtering, spectral analysis, time-frequency analysis and wavelet transform. A particular emphasis will be placed on providing the necessary mathematical tools.

During the semester also a group work dedicated to one particular field of solid waste treatment will be performed in parallel to the class. The result of this project will be presented at the end of the semester. Most of the learning content and necessary preparation of the excursions remains to be done as homework. The time in the class will be used for discussions and interaction between teacher and students.
Normally every afternoon is representing a new and independent learning bloc related to a particular field or aspect of waste management or treatment technology (see content above). The course is taking place in the afternoon 2-5pm, however, some field excursions may take longer and for 1 excursion the travel to the field requires to leaving EPFL already at 1pm. The amount of field excursions at which a student is allowed to participate may be reduced in case the class is taken by more than 24 students. The time would be compensated by additional exercises and homework.
Students who can participate full time and are ready to invest in homework will appreciate this course. The joint experience and participation in the excursions as a group is essential. The success of the class will depend on the participation and contribution of each student.

info.title: Aeroelasticity and fluid-structure interaction
info.exam_form_detail: There will be a midterm exam worth 30% and a written final exam worth 70% of the grade.
info.content: This course will articulate the most common types of fluid-structure interactions and associated dynamic behaviour: externally-induced excitation, motion-induced excitation, and instability-induced excitation.  The focus however will be on flow-induced structural motion and on the onset of instabilities resulting from the latter two cases. Both discrete and continuous systems are analysed. A number of problems of engineering interest will be presented to elucidate the perils of neglecting fluid-structure coupling and how to mitigate undesirable phenomena. Both static and dynamic instabilities will be discussed.

info.title: Architecture and construction of the city I
info.content:
This series of courses will consist of a theoretical introduction, a presentation of historical references and an analysis of recent projects.

The discussion of the modes of openness will be based on the texts of Pétrarque, Laugier and C.Sitte, and on analysis of drawings of Le Corbusier and Louis Kahn.

The historical references will question the emergence and the transformation of types and textures, and analyze specific situations such as the Capitoline Hill in Rome, the Piazza San Marco in Venice, and the evolution of the royal places in Paris from the Place des Vosges to the Place de la Concorde.

Case studies will discuss works of outstanding figures such as Terragni or Asplund, and recent realisations, with the aim to clarify possible articulations between analysis and projects.
info.learning_outcomes:
« Here and there » - this is the question by which we will tackle the modes of constitution of urban places : how can the character of a place be determined by its relationship to the distance?

We will have to clarify the contributions of architecture to the structuring of public spaces, through the discussion of phenomena of openness, in both senses :
• availability to transformations, without exhausting all the possibilities of interpretations,
• figures of spaces without strict boundaries, without being vague or dispersed.

title: Architecture and construction of the city I

info.title: Architecture and construction of the city II
info.content:
This series of courses will consist of a theoretical introduction, a presentation of historical references and an analysis of recent projects.

The presence of the infrastructures will be introduced by the analysis of works by Hopper and Valéry.

The mode of analysis will be mainly drawing. The relevance of possible strategies will be discussed, with particular attention to the articulation between analysis and project.
info.learning_outcomes:
Structures and infrastructures

« Here and elsewhere » - this is the complementary question which will be the subject of a second series of lectures. How can the character of a place be determined by its relationship to scales that evoke «otherness»? Railroads, embankments, and the multiplication of grounds will be taken as opportunities to analyze the structure of urban places and to identify modes of interventions concerned with local correspondences to the structures of our territories.

title: Architecture and construction of the city II

info.content:

Solar conversion efficiency measurements and analysis of devices with electrochemical impedance spectroscopy.

info.learning_outcomes: Dye sensitized solar cell (DSC) is a new low-cost technology that converts sunlight directly to the electricity. The focus of the course will be to understand the operating principle of DSC with going in details of their mechanistic process involved in detail.

info.content:
Option 1 : Creative toolbox for innovation
Each first term course will be focused on the presentation of a creation approach.

Sessions will be based on case studies coming from contemporary arts and design with practical activities and exercises:
1. Preliminary research methods: iconographic research, exploration of failures and accidents, role of user observations and evolution of technical objects as inspiration source, observation sketches, role of analogies, mood boards.
2. Creation and prototyping techniques: story-boarding/storytelling, 3D mock-ups, graphic design, digital interface creation (website, mobile service, networked object), repurposing of standard software (powerpoint, excel).

The topics we will address for each of these approaches will deal with pictures, motion pictures, interfaces (web/physical artifacts) and 3D representations.

During the second semester, students will work on a project based on a specific topic they will have to choose and the combination of two research approaches plus two creation methods.

Option 2: cinéma du réel between fiction and documentary
Finding the voices that relate true stories, at the heart of contemporary film
Presentations accompanied by viewings of numerous film excerpts. Putting some theoretical reference texts into perspective.
Initiation in the fundamental practices of sound taking and shooting.
Approach to editing and post-production.
From the completed shooting to the construction of the narrative, the main stages of reflection and action necessary to "make a film".

Option 1 : Creative toolbox for innovation
Give students the opportunity to discover, understand and apply various creative approaches, by highlighting the diversity of methodologies and the relevance of subjectivity or intuition.

Option 2: cinéma du réel between fiction and documentary
To deploy a geography of contemporary cinematographic creation, to define its identities and gauge the issues relating to the areas of influence and hybridations, between documentary and fiction.
By making very short films, then a more ambitious film, to initiate the building of a viewpoint that lends meaning to filmed reality. The technical and aesthetic choices go hand-in-hand to construct a narrative made of dramaturgically justified periods and moments.

info.title: Astrophysics I : Introduction to astrophysics
info.content:
1. The origin of science: the role of astronomy and astrophysics from Antiquity to the present.
2. Basic knowledge: spherical astronomy, telescopes, detectors and observations; concepts of photometry, magnitudes, spectroscopy; radiation mechanism; celestial mechanics.
3. Solar system: the Sun, the Earth and the Moon, planets and asteroids; extrasolar planets; formation of planetary systems; origin of life.
4. The stars: nuclear energy and nucleo-synthesis of elements; stellar evolution of stars with various masses; white dwarfs, neutron stars, black holes, star clusters and Herzsprung-Russell diagram.
5. The interstellar medium: dust, gas and interstellar molecules.
6. The Milky Way, our Galaxy: stellar populations; galactic differential rotation; spiral structure.
7. The galaxies: classification; luminosity and mass distribution in regular galaxies; active galactic nuclei and quasars; supermassive black holes; galaxy clusters; formation and evolution of galaxies.
8. Cosmology: Newtonian cosmology; general relativity and cosmology; history of the Universe; formation of large scale structures; observational constraints; dark matter, dark energy.

2. Potential theory.

3. The orbits of stars.

4. Equilibria of collisionless systems.

5. Stability of collisionless systems.

6. Disk dynamics.

7. Kinetic theory: relaxation processes, thermodynamics of self-gravitating systems, Fokker-Planck approximation.

8. Collisions and encounters of stellar systems

info.type_of_teaching: Ex cathedra and exercises supervised in classroom

title: Astrophysics III : Stellar and galactic dynamics

info.title: Astrophysics IV : Observational cosmology
info.prior_knowledge: Bachelor in physics or mathematics and Astrophysics I, II and III
info.content:
1. A brief historical perspective: a few ancient cosmologies. Olbers' paradox.
2. The three observational pillars of Big Bang cosmology dis-covered during the 20th century: (i) The universe expansion; (ii) The cosmic microwave background at 3K; (iii) The abundance of light elements.
3. The metric of the universe. The spectral redshifts.
4. Cosmological models and the evolution of the universe.
5. Observational tests: the age of the universe, mean density and the problem of dark matter, nucleo-cosmo-chronology, the deep galaxy counts.
6. Recent observations of the cosmic microwave background and its power spectrum.
7. Impact of gravitational lenses on cosmology.
8. The initial phases of the evolution of the universe in the Big Bang model and cosmological nucleosynthesis.
info.learning_outcomes: Cosmology is the study of the structure and evolution of the universe as a whole. This course describes the principal themes of cosmology, as seen from the point of view of observations.
info.type_of_teaching: Ex cathedra and exercices supervised in classroom

info.title: Audio engineering
info.content:
Audio Engineering is the whole range of techniques related to audible sounds and involves the different processes, equipment and systems for the production, transmission, recording of sound but also measurement and modification of sound fields. This course provides a solid basis for the study, conception and design of audio equipment. An appropriate balance between theory and practical applications leads to a thorough grasp of the main aspects of the problems. Numerous examples and demonstrations illustrate the techniques and methods proposed. The applications and processes, from classical methods to the most recent ones, such as digital audio, are described from the basic concept right up to the practical applications.

This second semester is devoted to the essential aspects of the following chapters:
- Electroacoustic transducers
- Loudspeakers and loudspeaker systems
- Microphones
- Active control

info.learning_outcomes:
To master the audio basics, models and methods.
To be able to model and design an audio device or system.
To acquire knowledge of the main audio techniques and know how to conceive and design different devices, apparatus and transducers.
info.type_of_teaching: Ex cathedra with demonstrations, examples ands exercises

info.title: Automatic speech processing
info.content:
1. Introduction: Speech processing tasks, language engineering applications.

2. Basic Tools: Analysis and spectral properties of the speech signal, linear prediction algorithms, statistical pattern recognition, dynamic programming.

3. Speech Coding: Human hearing properties, quantization theory, speech coding in the temporal and frequency domains.

4. Speech Synthesis: Morpho-syntactic analysis, phonetic transcription, prosody, speech synthesis models.

5. Automatic Speech Recognition: Temporal pattern matching and Dynamic Time Warping (DTW) algorithms, speech recognition systems based on Hidden Markov Models (HMMs).

6. Speaker recognition and speaker verification: Formalism, hypothesis testing, HMM based speaker verification.

7. Linguistic Engineering: state-of-the-art and typical applications
info.library_recomm: • "Traitement de la parole / René Boite ... [et al.]". Year:2000. ISBN:2-88074-388-5
info.learning_outcomes: The goal of this course is to provide the students with the main formalisms, models and algorithms required for the implementation of advanced speech processing applications (involving, among others, speech coding, speech analysis/synthesis, and speech recognition).

info.title: Biological chemistry I

• Introduction to the structure and function of biomolecules.
• Structure and function of amino acids, properties of side groups and their influence on protein structure.
• Chemical properties of the peptide bond. Structure and function of biologically active peptides.
• Protein structure. Primary structure, hydrogen bonding, hydrophobic bonding, electrostatic and Van der Waals forces. Secondary structure, alpha-helix, beta-sheet and other aspects of protein folding. Acquisition of tertiary structure, unfolding and refolding of proteins. Quaternary structure. Probing protein structure. The Prion Diseases.
• Structure and function of myoglobin and haemoglobin. Molecular pathology of haemoglobin. Interactions between proteins and ligands: antibody-antigen interactions as an example.
• Introduction to enzymes. I.U.B. classification of enzymes. Catalytic power. Enzyme specificity. Active site and ES complex. Introduction to enzyme kinetics, Michaelis-Menten. Factors which influence enzyme reaction rate. Enzyme inhibition. Regulatory enzymes.
• Structure and chemical properties of monosaccharides and oligosaccharides. Nomenclature, conformations and glycosidic linkages in oligosaccharides. Structure, function and properties of starch, cellulose, agarose, glycoaminoglycans, proteoglycan. Diabetes.
• Nomenclature, structure and properties of nucleic acids. Molecular structure of DNA and RNA. Nucleic acid chemistry. Structure and function of ATP and NAD(H). Basics of ATP generation in the cell.
• Structure and characteristics of lipids. Summary of their function in membranes, storage and transport of metabolic fuel.

• To develop the student's understanding of the relationship between the structure and biological function of biomolecules.
• To enable the student to recognize and understand the structural characteristics of component small molecules that dictate the final structure of multi-component macromolecules.
• To establish the student's appreciation of the structural features in macromolecules that take part in specific interactions with both small molecules and other macromolecules.
• To illustrate the importance of a sound understanding of structure and function through examples drawn from molecular pathology, protein engineering and protein modification.

info.title: Biomechanics of the cardiovascular system
info.content:
Introduction
Physics of living matter and biomedical engineering; anatomy and physiology of the cardiovascular system
Biophysics of the blood
Blood rheology; mechanical properties of red blood cells.
Cardiac mechanics
Mechanical activity of the heart; biomechanics of the cardiac muscle; Pressure-volume diagram; Frank-Starling laws of the heart; Varying elastance principle; Pump function graphs; Cardiac energetics; Arterio-ventricular coupling; Windkessel effect.
Hemodynamics and biomechanics of the arterial system
Structure, passive and active mechanical properties of the arterial wall; pulsatile blood flow in a rigid tube, model of Womersley; propagation of pressure and flow waves in an elastic tube; reflection and attenuation of waves in arteries; physical models of the arterial system; blood-vessel wall interactions.
Microcirculation
Hemodynamics in capillaries; exchange of substances and liquids across the capillary wall.
Biomechanics of the venous system
Biomechanics of the venous wall; flow in collapsible tubes; "Waterfall" phenomenon.
info.learning_outcomes:
To present the students with the concepts and principles of Cardiac and Vascular Biomechanics.
To describe the physical phenomena observed in the cardiovascular system and to present the models used for their interpretation.

info.title: Building materials + Laboratory work

info.content:
- Function of construction materials, historic and geographic perspective.
Concrete
- Fabrication of cement, microstructural formation.
- Applications technology, practically imposed demands and limits.
- Evolution of early age properties.
- Mechanical behaviour, cracking and failure, viscoelasticity.

info.learning_outcomes:
The objective of this course and the related laboratory work is to familiarize the students with the different functions of materials in construction: the composition and structure of the most used (non metallic) building materials - principally concrete, but also glass, masonry and wood.

The composition and formation of microstructure are examined, in order to establish the link between their behaviour under mechanical loads and environmental exposure (durability).

info.title: Building physics I
info.content:
Building-environment interactions: the sun, wet air, wind impacts, hygrothermal comfort.

Heat transfer principles: conduction, convection, radiation, evaporation and condensation.
info.learning_outcomes:
At the end of the semester the students will be able to:

• determine the sun path for any given latitude;

• draw building shadows and determine the appropriate size of sun shades;

• use a psychrometric diagram (relative humdity, dew point);

• calculate orders of magnitude of wind pressure on building envelopes;

• calculate the thermal resistance (and U value) of a multi layers wall;

• identify weaknesses in the thermal insulation of buildings;

• build-up comfort zones using different diagrams.

info.title: Building physics II
info.content:

Photometry/Colorimetry: luminous and chromatic proper-ties of building materials.
info.learning_outcomes:
At the end of the semester the students will be able to:

• quantify and use sound levels;

• determine the sound level resulting from the superposition of coherent and incoherent sound waves;

• evaluate the sound level dampening due to distance and sound screens;

• assess the acoustic quality of a building space;

• differentiate the main photometric quantities;

• appreciate the luminous properties of glazing and building materials;

• characterize the colorimetric properties of a luminous flux.

info.title: Building physics III
info.content:
Non-transparent construction materials (walls, roof).

Hygro-thermal balance of walls.

Thermal insulation and acoustic protection.

Impact of the building thermal inertia.
info.learning_outcomes:
At the end of the semester the students will be able to:

• determine the temperature and vapor pressure distributions within a multi-layer wall;

• assess and improve the acoustic properties of a building space;

• select building construction materials according to the building surrounding noise and acoustic constrains;

• select building construction materials according to outdoor/indoor thermal constrains.

info.title: Building physics IV

Windows physical features.

Solar gains and thermal losses.

Advanced day lighting systems.

• compare windows performance by the way of the most significant physical parameters (U, g, t, a);

• determine the solar gains and thermal losses of a building;

• assess the impact of different sunshades;

• determine the day lighting contribution for different room positions and assess complementary electric lighting needs;

Building energy design and analysis tools.

• optimise the building energy balance and thermal comfort by way of design tools;

• quantify eventual building cooling loads;

• determine and apply the appropriate measures to reduce building cooling loads.

info.title: Building physics VI
info.content:
Optimal energy management within buildings.

Heat recovery techniques.

Solar energy collectors.

Heat storage technology.

Building energy analysis methods.

Building energy management methods.
info.learning_outcomes:
At the end of the semester the students will be able to:

• perform building diagnostics regarding energy performance;

• determine the energy savings contribution of different heat recovery devices;

• identify and design different passive and active solar energy systems;

• identify and design different heat storage processes and technologies.

info.bibliography: Philip Kotler, Marketing Management, Prentice Hall
info.title: Business plan for IT services
info.content:
The students, working as groups, have to:
(1) Imagine an IT service to develop,
(2) Identify and analyze the relevant markets, validate their understanding with interviews of target customers and partners,
(3) define the qualitative and quantitative goals for their project,
(4) check the financial viability of their project.

Topics : segmentation, assumption surfacing, value creation, competitive analysis, strategy canvas, inter-organization relationship, and simple financial analysis. The Amazon company is extensively analyzed to illustrate these concepts.
info.library_recomm: • "Marketing management / Philip Kotler, Kevin Lane Keller". Year:2009. ISBN:978-0-13-135797-6
info.learning_outcomes:
Services are becoming the main providers of value in many market economies. Services are increasingly dependent on IT. Many enterprises or entrepreneurs risk failure because they design products rather than services. Even basic products need minimal services without which they cannot be sold (e.g. warranty, customer service).

In this course you will work in teams. You will choose an idea of IT service and analyze the business environnment of this service. You will then design a business model for your IT service. To do so, you will use traditional marketing methods as well as SEAM - an innovative method that provide a systemic model of a business.

info.title: Cancer Biology I
info.prerequisite_for:
Master in life sciences & technology, specialization in molecular
medicine.
info.content:
The 2x5 credit course starts in the fall semester and continues throughout the spring semester. In the fall semester, the following topics are covered:

1. Tumorigenesis (chemical & physical carcinogenesis, infectious disease and cancer, cancer susceptibility/heredity, tumor clonality).
2. Oncogenic signaling (the cell cycle, genome stability, replicative
potential, epigenetic regulation of gene expression, apoptosis, signal
transduction, intercellular communication).
info.prior_knowledge: Basic knowledge of molecular biology and genetics.
info.library_recomm: • "The biology of cancer / Robert A. Weinberg". Year:2007. ISBN:0-8153-4078-8
info.learning_outcomes: Introduction to the basic cellular processes that underlie the initiation and progression of cancer.

info.title: Cancer Biology II
info.prerequisite_for: Master in life sciences & bio technology, specialization in molecular medicine
info.content:
The 2x5 credit course Cancer Biology I+II starts in the winter semester and continues throughout the summer semester. Cancer Biology II covers:
1. Oncogenic signaling (relevant signal transduction pathways, intercellular communication, signal regulation and modularity, complex signaling networks).
2. Tumorigenesis (chemical & physical carcinogenesis; infectious disease and cancer; cancer susceptibility/heredity; tumor clonality; examples for malignancies).
3. Tumor-host interactions (tumor angiogenesis; epithelial-mesenchymal transition, dissemination and metastasis; proteolysis; inflammation; immune evasion; immuno editing).
4. Mechanism-based therapies (chemotherapy; response to therapy; concepts and examples of drug discovery; therapeutic targets; targeted therapies; current clinical trials; immuno therapy).

The weekly lectures will be followed by exercises. The task for these exercises will be student presentations of reviews and scientific articles which illustrate the course and to consolidate the knowledge of the course topics.
info.library_recomm: • "The biology of cancer / Robert A. Weinberg". Year:2007. ISBN:0-8153-4078-8
info.learning_outcomes:
The student comprehends how known alterations in physiological mechanisms required for tissue homeostasis can be tumorigenic:
- names key components of tumor suppressor and oncogenic signaling pathways and distinguishes their functions
- identifies regulatory principles in tumor-relevant complex signaling networks
- can use such insight to explain mechanism-based therapies and identify gaps in the current knowledge.

info.title: Catalysis for energy production
info.content:
1. Introduction to energy demand and challenge
2. Hydrogen: production, storage, fuel cell
3. Oxygen: oxygen reduction water oxidation

info.learning_outcomes: To learn how catalysis can improve energy generation and utilization. Emphasis is on the production, storage and conversion of solar fuels (H2, O2, etc...).

info.title: Catalyst design for synthesis
info.content:
• Organometallic chemistry: revision of basic ideas including structure and bonding and the implications this has on reactivity of an organic ligand coordinated to a metal centre.

• A description of the reactions involved in homogeneous catalysis, with an emphasis on the essential features required to predict which type of reactions can take place.

• General classification of different types of catalysts and their industrial relevance/importance.

• With an emphasis on the mechanistics the following types of reactions will be studied: hydrogenation, carbonylation, hydroformylation, isomerisation, metathesis (ring opening and ring closing), carbon-carbon coupling (e.g. Heck, Suzuki and Stille reactions).


• Ligand design, i.e. modification of ligands in order to produce more efficient and selective catalysts, will be discussed. Enan-tioselective ligands that give optically pure products will also be considered.


• Methods to immobilise homogeneous catalysts in alternative sol-vents (biphasic catalysis) will be explored with an emphasis on the strategies available and how to modify the catalyst to operate under the different conditions.
info.learning_outcomes: The goal of the course will be to provide an understanding of the methods for making organic compounds using transition metal catalysts. The design process for developing superior catalysts to those currently in use will be explored and methods to recycle homogeneous catalysts evaluated.

2. Asymmetric activation of nucleophiles with metal-and organo-catalysts.
3. Dual activation with acid-base, metal-base, metal-metal and single metal systems.
4. Umpolung of reactivity.
info.learning_outcomes: Underdstanding of principles of catalysis in organic synthesis. Knowledge of recent developments in the area and applications for the synthesis of chiral building blocks. Ability to understand and assay the quality or research articles in the area.

title: Catalytic asymmetric reactions in organic chemistry

info.title: Cavitation and interface phenomena
info.content:
INTRODUCTION, BASIC CONCEPTS:
- Definitions, history, effects and types of cavitation
- Liquid-Vapor transition, tensile strength
- Static equilibrium of a nuclei, role of surface tension
CAVITATION BUBBLE COLLAPSE:
- Dynamics of an isolated bubble : Rayleigh-Plesset equation
- Micro-jetting, shock waves, sonoluminescence
- Bubble collapse in the vicinity of a solid wall
- Bubble collapse in the vicinity of a plane free surface
- Bubble collapse within confined volumes (jets and drops)
- Effect of acceleration field (i.e. : gravity)
- Cavitation erosion mechanism
- Thermodynamic effects
DYNAMIQUE DES CAVITS ATTACHÉES :
- Onset and stability of attached cavitation
- Mechanism of transient cavities shedding
- Role of the boundary layer (roughness) and pressure gradient
- Cavitation aggressiveness
- Scale effects
CAVITATION IN VORTICALSTRUCTURES :
- Tip vortex cavitation, nuclei and Reynolds effects
- Cavitation in von Karman vortices
INDUSTRIAL APPLICATIONS:
- Cavitation in hydraulic machines
- Model testing of cavitation in hydraulic machines
- Techniques for Cavitation monitoring
info.learning_outcomes:
Domain skills:
• Describe a flow in scientific terms, AH1
• Link flow behaviour with non-dimensional parameters (e.g. Reynolds and Mach numbers), AH2
• Describe cavitation and its consequences in physical terms; predict the appearance of cavitation pockets in the flow, AH8
• Provide a characterization of complex physical behaviour, such as multiphase flow and combustion, AH9


Transversal skills:
• Take notes effectively, T3
• Do a literature review and assess the state of the art, T4
• Faire un résumé d'un article ou d'un document technique, T5

During this course, we will discuss:
1. How cell division is regulated
2. The cell's cytoskeleton; its functions and their regulation
3. An introduction to genetics
4. How cells communicate with each other
5. An introduction to the cell and molecular biology of higher order cellular organizations in tissues, their homeostasis and repair by stem cells and how misregulation of these processes can lead to cancer.

The environmental issues related to CO2 release and the concept of CO2 neutral fuels will be introduced. Then, natural photosynthesis and the artificial mimicking of photosynthesis will be taught. The course will cover thermodynamic principles of energy conversion, technical processes involving biomass, bio-gas and liquid bio-fuels, natural gas usage, various types of solar energy conversion methods and principles, low carbon fuels, hydrogen economy, electrolysis and photoelectrolysis of water, fuel cells, and bio-fuel cell principles.The use of renewable energy for mobility applications will also be dealt with.

info.title: Chemical thermodynamics I
info.content:
1. First principle: work and heat
Fundamental variables of state, internal energy, closed and open systems.

2. Second principle: Entropy
Statistical (Boltzmann) and thermodynamic interpretation, reversible and irreversible processes, equilibrium state, heat engines (Carnot, Strirling).


3. Auxiliary variables of state
Enthalpy, free enthalpy and free energy, their interpretation and usefulness. Fundamental equations and characteristic variables. Maxwell relations, chemical potential.

4. Treatment of mixture
Molar and partial molar quantities.

5. General treatment of chemical reactions
Extend of reaction, reaction variables (reaction enthalpy entropy and free enthalpy), standard state, heat of reaction, heat of formation of chemical compounds.

6. Thermodynamics of gases
Ideal and real gases, fugacity, state equations (Van der Waals equation, virial coefficients). Joule Thompson effect.

7. Chemical reactions in the gas phase
Mass action law, equilibrium constant, Kirchhoff's rule and Van t'Hoff equation.

8. Phase equilibria of pure compounds
Clausius-Clapeyron equation, phase diagram, supercritical state.
info.library_recomm: • "The bases of chemical thermodynamics / Michael Graetzel, Pierre Infelta". Year:2000. ISBN:1-58112-772-3
info.learning_outcomes: Develop a solid basis of the thermodynamic theory and use it for chemical applications.

info.title: Chemical thermodynamics II
info.content:
1. Phase equilibria in mixtures
Gibbs phase rule.

2. Heterogeneous chemical reactions
Linearly independent reactions in complex systems.


3. Ideal solutions
Chemical potential (statistical derivation). Raoult's and Henry's law, separation of compounds in mixtures by distillation, Nernst distribution law and chromatic separation osmotic pressure, boiling point elevation and freezing point depression, eutectic point.

4. Real solutions
Standard states, activity coefficients, Phase diagrams, azeotropic mixtures, Gibbs-Duhem's rule, excess functions for the formation of mixtures.

5. Regular solutions
Macromolecules (polymers) in solution, Flory Huggin's theory.

6. Chemical reactions in solution
Euqilibirum constants, dependence on pressure and temperature, chemical potential of electrolytes and enthalpy of formation of ions in solution, thermodynamics of physiologically important reactions.


7. Basic concepts of irreversible reactions in open systems
Biological applications.
info.library_recomm: • "The bases of chemical thermodynamics / Michael Graetzel, Pierre Infelta". Year:2000. ISBN:1-58112-771-5
info.learning_outcomes: Develop a solid base of  thermodynamic theory and treat its  chemical applications.

info.title: City and Habitat : from housing to territory
info.content: This course will address urban dynamics starting from urban and regional structures and transportation and communication networks, analyzed with reference to sustainable urban development. This entry will allow addressing housing, urban sprawl, relegation and gentrification in metropolitan areas in North and South. The housing question will be taken up again at the larger scale of city and region. The role of mobility in these transformations will be addressed, as well as public policies and private strategies regarding urban development.
info.learning_outcomes: This course prepares to the analysis of urban and regional development from the social and economic points of view. It studies in particular in terms of processes the spatial organization of activities, actors and the main issues of habitat, land use, mobilities as well as the durability of urban development.

title: City and Habitat : from housing to territory

info.title: City and mobility
info.content:
The aims of this course are:

1) to describe recent developments in urban mobility in Europe;
2) to understand the thinking that underpins mobility behaviour;
3) to evaluate the possibilities of regulating mobility according to supply (in terms of infrastructure and services), in particular possible ways to encourage a modal shift from car use to other means of transport.
info.learning_outcomes:
The issue of modal share

Over the last twenty years, urban mobility has undergone sweeping changes. The number of leisure trips has increased, while the share of commuting trips has shrunk. At the same time, new forms of mobility have appeared, such as multiple residences, long-distance commuting, urban tourism and day-trips. These are accompanied by a significant rise in the number of kilometres travelled by car and by plane, which in turn generates considerable environmental problems. Mobility is an issue for urban transport design and territorial development. If we are to regulate mobility, we have to re-think our understanding of transport demand.

info.title: City sciences I
info.content:
• Why the sciences of the urban?
• The city as event: urbanisation.
• The city as way of life: urbaneness.
• Models of the city.
• The city as action: urban planning.
• The city at stake.
• Cities of the World: New York, Los Angeles, Paris, Berlin, Tokyo, Hong Kong.
info.learning_outcomes:
This course aims to help the students to orientate themselves, by the means of an interdisciplinary perspective, within the knowledge produced by the sciences of the urban.

It is about fundamental research complementary to the different courses on the project and action. We will focus on the definition of the fundamental concepts (city, urban, urbaneness, public space, metropolisation, etc.). We will also give a quantitative and qualitative overview of global urbanisation, and then explore the different dimensions of contemporary urbaneness. Urban planning will be addressed as a specific object, that is, as a relation it establishes between knowledge and action.

Finally, the city and urban issues, at stake in contemporary society, are approached. This analysis is enriched by the study of some metropolises, which are also "global cities".

This course will be especially oriented toward the notion of public space. This takes place in the scope of a CUS-supported co-operation programme called USUM (Urban Systems, Urban Models), involving, beyond Chôros/EPFL, the ETH Studio Basel and the Mendrisio Accademia (USI). Members of those two schools will participate in the course. The film-making process will focus on the analysis of a public space.

info.title: City sciences II
info.content: See City sciences I.
info.learning_outcomes: See City sciences I.

info.title: Civil system project
info.content:
Definition and modelisation of a civil engineering system. Analysis of the behaviour of the system and possible improvements and enhancement. Systematic simulations of the system and parameter analysis. Optimisation of the system by adding of new elements. Performance analysis of the system. Technical report with detailed description of the system (including schemas and computer code) and the results obtained by systematic simulations. Executive summmary.

Team project based on a general project program established by professors in charge.
info.learning_outcomes: Analysis and optimisation of a system in the field of civil engineering such as LOGISTICS AND MANAGEMENT, WATER, ENERGY, TRANSPORTATION AND LAND PLANNING.

info.title: Classical electrodynamics
info.prerequisite_for: Plasma physics, optics and theoretical physics
info.content:
I Magnetostatics and electrostatics: vector and scalar potential, Coulomb's law, Ampère's law, law of Biot and Savart.

II Maxwell's equations: Faraday's law, Maxwell's equations in differential and integral form, scalar and vector potentials, gauge transformations, solutions of Maxwell's equations in the vacuum, solutions of Maxwell's equations in the presence of charges and currents, retarded potentials, Liénard-Wiechert potentials, emission of waves.


III Special relativity: Galilei transformations versus Lorentz transformations, quadrivectors, Maxwell's equations in quadridimensional form, relativistic particle dynamics.

IV Electric and magnetic fields in macroscopic media: equations of macroscopic electrodynamics, boundary conditions, waves in continuous media; reflection and refraction of waves.

info.learning_outcomes:
To present the unity of electric and magnetic phenomena.
To study the properties of electric and magnetic fields and electromagnetic waves in the vacuum and in macroscopic media. Maxwell's equations as a clue for special relativity.

Clean room environment, security aspects, process flow chart.

• a photolithography step with alignment
• a wet or dry etching step
Several methods will be used to characterize the effect of the process parameters on the quality and resolution of the patterned microstructures.

info.title: Climate and climate change
info.exam_form_detail: Continuous control and final written exam
info.content:
• Radiation and global energy balance
• Atmospheric circulation
• Oceanic circulation
• Ocean/Atmosphere interactions
• Carbon cycle (and other greenhouse gases)
• Long-term climate regulation
• Climate models
• Energy and the environment
info.learning_outcomes: The objective of this course is to provide a quantitative description of the processes driving current climate changes including the interactions among various components of the Earth system such as atmosphere, oceans, land surface and biosphere. We will discuss how climate has changed in the past. We will examine the evidence for current climate change and the environmental impact of human use of energy on the climate of the future.
info.type_of_teaching: Lecture ex cathedra and in-class discussions of scientific papers

Digital Color Imaging Handbook (ed. G. Sharma), CRC Press, 2003
info.title: Color reproduction
info.prerequisite_for: Master project in the field (possibly in industry)
info.exam_form_detail: With continuous control : Laboratories, mini-project and oral final exam
info.content:
Color theory:
Illuminants, spectral sensibility of the eye, colorimetric equalization, the CIE-XYZ, xyY, CIELAB, RGB, YIQ, CMYK color systems.


Interaction between light and printed paper
Elements of radiometry, Beer's law, the Saunderson correction (multiple reflections) and the Clapper-Yule spectral reflection prediction model.

Color devices: Modellization of scanners (+ cameras), cameras, displays and printers, black-white and color printing, density measurements, color separation, device characterization (scanner, display, printer), gamut mapping, color prediction models (Neugebauer, Yule-Nielson), dot gain models, fitting of unknown parameters by optimization techniques.



Halftoning algorithms
Clustered-dot dithering, dispersed-dot dithering, super-cells, error diffusion, moiré phenomena between color layers, color halftoning.


The course is coupled with laboratories in MatLab which enable exercising the concepts presented during the lectures. A small R&D project enables every student to gain concrete experience with some of the course's topics.
info.library_recomm: • "Digital color imaging handbook / ed. by Gaurav Sharma". Year:2003. ISBN:978-1-4200-4148-4
info.learning_outcomes: The course introduces the fundaments of colorimetry, as well as models for displays, scanners, digital cameras and printers. The main focus is on halftoning and color reproduction (color separation, interaction between light and prints, gamut mapping, color prediction). The reviewed concepts are useful for the understanding of anti-counterfeiting methods (protective features for banknotes, checks, etc).
info.type_of_teaching: Lecture, laboratories and small R&D project

info.title: Combinatorial optimization
info.content:
Paths and Trees (Connectivity, Shortest Path, Minimum Spanning Tree).

Cycles, Flow, and Cuts (Negative Cycles, Minimum Mean Cycles, Max Flow, Min Cut, Min Cost Network Flow).

Matchings (Bipartite, Non-bipartite).
info.learning_outcomes: This lecture will cover a selection of problems in Combinatorial Optimization. On this basis, the students will learn the relation between polyhedra and efficiency. This involves correctness proofs and objective to enhance the mathematical modelling skills of the students to enable them to recognize and exploit combinatorial optimization problems in broader contexts. Assignments will monitor the learning progress of the students.

info.title: Complex structures
info.content:
Different types and levels of complexity will be discussed:

• Structural complexity (space, membrane, pneumatic, freeform structures).
• Natural constructions (minimal path, tensegrity, branched, fractal structures).
• Form-finding methods (experimental, evolutionary algorithms).
• Advanced materials (advanced composites, glass).
• Material-structure interaction (ideal, constructible and implemented form).
• Hybrid construction (material combinations, composite action, joining).
• Multifunctional structures (structure-envelope integration).
• Complex program requirements (modular, convertible, flexible structures).
info.learning_outcomes: Discussion of factors that may increase the complexity of a load-bearing structure, such as spatial restrictions, material economy, hybrid construction, function-integration, program requirements and demonstration of the ways in which these can be implemented.

To introduce the latest developments in the field of polymer composites by presenting novel processing techniques, design concepts and the latest generations of composite materials and structures.
To illustrate material selection, design, processing and implementation by discussing real application examples.

info.title: Compressible-fluid dynamics
info.content: Review on fundamental and thermodynamics equations. Stationary and ideal one-dimensional compressible flow and compressibility evaluation. Normal shock waves. Oblique shock waves .Prandtl-Meyer expansion. Basic equations of a perfect and stationary quasi one-dimensional flow applied to Laval nozzle. Perfect and stationary two-dimensional flow through the method of calculation of the characteristics and the theory of weak perturbations. Pressure, lift and drag coefficients.

info.title: Computational linear algebra
info.content:
Introduction
Sources of large-scale linear algebra problems, sparsity, conditioning. Recap of required linear algebra concepts.

Linear systems
Direct sparse factorizations. Krylov subspace methods and preconditioners. Linear least-squares problems. Available software.

Eigenvalue problems
Preconditioned iterative methods. Krylov subspace methods. Singular value problems. Available software.

Implementation aspects
Efficient implementation on modern computer architectures, including multi-core processors, GPUs, and distributed memory machines. Available software.

Advanced linear algebra techniques
Compressed sensing, robust low-rank approximation, low-rank tensor approximation.
info.learning_outcomes: This course provides an overview of state-of-the-art techniques for solving large-scale linear algebra problems, as they typically arise in applications. Moreover, implementation aspects on multi-core and parallel architectures are discussed.
info.type_of_teaching: Ex cathedra, exercises in computer room

info.title: Computational linguistics
info.content:
Several models and algorithms for automated textual data processing will be described: (1) morpho-lexical level: electronic lexica, spelling checkers, ...; (2) syntactic level: regular, context-free, stochastic grammars, parsing algorithms, ...; (3) semantic level: models and formalisms for the representation of meaning, ... ; (4) pragmatic level: models and formalisms for dialogue management, contextual interpretation, speech acts.

Several application domains will be presented: Linguistic engineering, Information Retrieval, Text mining (automated knowledge extraction), Textual Data Analysis (automated document classification, visualization of textual data).
info.learning_outcomes:
Efficient handling of textual data is an important requirement for modern information systems. In applications such as search engines on the Web, Text Mining systems (information extraction) or even advanced document processing systems (correction, summary, translation...), the use of techniques sensitive to the linguistic content represents nowadays a clear competitive advantage.
The objective of this course is to present the main models, formalisms and algorithms necessary for the development of applications in the field of documentary information processing. The concepts introduced during the lectures will be applied during practical sessions.
info.type_of_teaching: Ex cathedra; practical work on computer

- Hartree Fock (HF) and post HF methods
- Density Functional Theory (DFT)
- ab-initio molecular dynamics: Born-Oppenheimer vs. Car-Parrinello dynamics.

Advanced topics:
- Quantum description of the interaction of matter with light.
- Representation of electronic excited states.
- Time dependent density functional theory.
- Adiabatic vs. non-adiabatic molecular dynamics
- Nuclear quantum effects.
info.learning_outcomes:
-Introduction to ground and excited state
electronic structure methods
-Introduction to ab-initio molecular dynamics : form adiabatic to non-adiabatic dynamics.

title: Computational methods in molecular quantum mechanics

info.title: Computational molecular biology
info.prior_knowledge: (i) an interest in both computational methods and molecular biology and evolution; and (ii) a strong background in one of algorithms or (evolutionary) molecular biology and some reasonable acquaintance with the other.
info.content:
Specific problems to be covered include sequencing and assembly, multiple sequence alignment, phylogenetic reconstruction, and whole-genome comparisons and evolution. Three quarters of the course is lectures, with graded homework assignments, while the last quarter is devoted to presentations and discussions of current research papers by student teams.
The emphasis throughout is on algorithmic design and analysis, including proofs of correctness and new designs, using both combinatorial and statistical approaches.
info.learning_outcomes: To develop an understanding of the main algorithmic approaches used in solving computational problems that arise in the analysis of biomolecular data (such as DNA/RNA/aminoacid sequences, mass spectra of proteins, whole genomes, or gene expression levels).

info.title: Computational physics I
info.content:
Introduction: discretization, integration and finite differences.

Time evolution: Decay processes. Particle motion in various force fields. Oscillations, resonances, chaos. N-body gravitational problem. Rigid body motion. Euler, Euler-Cromer, Stormer-Verlet and Runge-Kutta schemes. Numerical stability analysis. Adaptive schemes with variable time step.

Space integration: 1-D case: equations of local thermodynamic equilibrium, Poisson's equation. 2-D case: electrostatics and magnetostatics. Shooting, finite difference and finite element schemes. Iterative methods: Gauss-Seidel, SOR.

Several applications will be made as exercises and practical work, with evaluation of the returned reports.
info.prior_knowledge: 1st year courses (Physics I, II, Numerical analysis, Computer science I, II)
info.library_recomm:
• "Computational physics / Nicholas J. Giordano, Hisao Nakanishi". Year:2006. ISBN:0-13-146990-8
  • "Computational physics : an introduction / Franz J. Vesely". Year:2001. ISBN:0-306-46631-7
info.learning_outcomes: The student will learn to tackle, formulate and solve physics problems using elementary numerical methods. To understand advantages and limitations of these methods. To extend the applications to problems which are difficult to treat using analytical methods. To learn how to use physical concepts to verify and validate numerical results. To control numerical convergence in order to estimate errors. To complement and illustrate various physics subjects from other courses (Physics I,II,III,IV, Analytical Mechanics).
info.type_of_teaching: Ex cathedra presentations, exercises and practical work under supervision

info.title: Computational physics II
info.content:
Continuation of Computational physics I

Space and time integration: Advection. Diffusion. Explicit schemes, finite differences. Von Neuman numerical spectral stability analysis. Courant-Friedrichs-Lewy condition. Diffusion and random walk: a Monte Carlo approach.

Wave propagation. Initial and boundary conditions. Eigenmodes and eigenvalues. Stability analysis. Waves in inhomogeneous media.

Quantum mechanics. Time-dependent Schrödinger equation. Semi-implicit, unitary scheme. Free particle, wave packet spreading. Potentiel barriers, tunneling. Harmonic oscillator, semi-classical limit. Eigenstates, time-independent Schrödinger equation. Potential well, bound states. Particle in a periodic potential, energy gaps.

A selection among various applications: statistical mechanics, Ising model, Monte Carlo approach, Metropolis algorithm. Signal sampling and filtering (Fourier). Fluid flows, Particle-In-Cell (PIC) method.

Several applications will be made as exercises and practical work, with evaluation of the returned reports.
info.prior_knowledge: 1st year courses (Physics I, II, Numerical analysis, Computer science I, II) and Computational physics I
info.library_recomm:
• "Computational physics / Nicholas J. Giordano, Hisao Nakanishi". Year:2006. ISBN:0-13-146990-8
  • "Computational physics : an introduction / Franz J. Vesely". Year:2001. ISBN:0-306-46631-7
info.learning_outcomes: The student will learn to tackle, formulate and solve physics problems using elementary numerical methods. To understand advantages and limitations of these methods. To extend the applications to problems which are difficult to treat with analytical methods. To learn how to use physical concepts to verify and validate numerical results. To control numerical convergence in order to estimate errors. To complement and illustrate various physics subjects from other courses (Physics I-IV, Analytical Mechanics).
info.type_of_teaching: Ex cathedra presentations, exercises and practical work under supervision

info.title: Computational physics III
info.exam_form_detail: Report during the semester with a final optional oral
info.content:
Linear Systems
Introduction and examples. Gauss-Jordan elimination, LU factorization.
Iterative refinement Tridiagonal and Band diagonal systems. Iterative
methods and Preconditioning: Jacobi, Richards and gradient methods.
Conjugate gradient method. Iterative vs direct methods.

Matrix manipulation and Eigenvalues problems
Introduction and examples. Properties and decomposition. Power
iteration. QR decomposition and iterative procedure. Singular Value
Decomposition (SVD).

Fourier Series and Trasforms
Introduction to the Fourier series and transforms and their application.
Mathematical properties:
convergence, convolution, correlation, Gibbs phenomenon and the
Wiener-Khinchin theorem. The Fourier transform on discrete sampled
data: aliasing and sampling theorem. The Discrete Fourier Transform
(DFT) and the Fast Fourier Transform (FFT). Applications: spectral
analysis, filters. Fourier transforms in higher dimensionality.

Statistical Analysis of data
Probability distribution functions: mean, variance and higher moments.
Examples of important distributions. Central limit theorem. Statistical
hypothesis testing: t-test, F-test and Chi-squared test. Estimation of
statistical errors, correlation and covariance. Approximation of data and
functions: interpolation, extrapolation and spline. Principal component
analysis (PCA).
info.learning_outcomes:
In this course the student will face some numerical problems that are typically encountered in modern physics. It is clear that, today, each physicist has to be familiar not only with the mathematical tools but also on the way to implement them numerical. This course is aimed not only to the student interested in computational physics but to all the students.

Specific objectives are:

- To learn to how to be confident with the numerical routines that are the daily toolbox of most physicist
- To develop a strong feeling of the differences between the mathematical modeling and its solution on a computer
- To get familiar with the available instruments for the fast and reliable of numerical problem
info.type_of_teaching: Ex cathedra presentations, exercises and work under supervision

info.title: Computer simulation of physical systems I
info.content:
Ordinary differential equations: methods for numerical integration: multistep algorithms and implicit algorithms.

Classical molecular dynamics: Verlet algorithm, predictor-corrector algorithms, determination of macroscopic parameters, Nosé-Hoover thermostat, constraints, Ewald summations, application to Lennard-Jones liquids.

Random variables: definitions and properties, generators and distribution functions, central-limit theorem.

Random walks: binomial and Gaussian distributions, particle diffusion, Brownian motion.

Monte Carlo integration: direct sampling, importance sampling, Metropolis algorithm, errors in correlated sampling, Monte-Carlo simulations of Lennard-Jones liquids and of two-dimensional spin systems.
info.learning_outcomes: To provide the student with basic methods of the computer simulation of physical systems.

title: Computer simulation of physical systems I

info.title: Computer simulation of physical systems II
info.content:
Diffusion-limited aggregation: description of the model, fractal dimension, dielectric breakdown.

Boundary and eigenvalue problems: Numerov's integration algorithm, solution of the radial Poisson equation and of the one-dimensional Schrödinger equation.

Density-functional theory: Hohenberg-Kohn theorem, Kohn-Sham equations, local-density approximation.


First-principles calculations: selfconsistent solutions for isolated atoms; selfconsistent solution for periodic systems, plane-wave basis sets, pseudopotentials; applications to atoms, clusters, solids, surfaces, chemical reactions.

Ab initio molecular dynamics: Car-Parrinello method and applications.


Variational Monte Carlo: solution of Schrödinger equation through the variational Monte Carlo method, variance minimization, application to quantum systems.

Diffusion Monte Carlo: solution of Schrödinger equation through evolution in imaginary time, Green-Function Monte Carlo method, guide function, fixed node approximation, application to quantum systems.


Minimization in multidimensions: steepest-descent and conjugate-gradient methods.
info.learning_outcomes: To provide the student with basic methods of computational condensed-matter physics.

First semester

Reliability: Surviving law, failure rate, reliability analysis, reliability of components, accelerated tests.
Project management: Organization, people, stimulation of creativity, time and money management, project reviews and audits.
Realization of a conceptual design project, from the basic idea to the beginning of the detailed design.

The results of the work will be presented in a final report.

info.title: Construction and sustainability I
info.content:
This course deals with the material elements of construction and the method of and approach to construction in parallel with the basic ideas about various construction materials and their use.

The two aspects - construction and materials - are dealt with in a logical sequence that will help students to understand the reciprocal relationship between the two subjects and to master their interdependence.

With the help of lectures and commented exercises, the course aims to teach knowledge and know-how in the field of construction.
info.learning_outcomes:
To provide the cornerstones for a global approach to construction and materials in view of an elementary, yet coherent mastery of techniques in an architectural project.

Students are intended to acquire

• the ability to observe and represent construction;
• a knowledge of systems and processes in connection with load-bearing and façade structures;
• a knowledge of the main construction materials and the techniques involved in their use;
• a logical understanding of the types of construction (construction geometries, the transmission of forces, stability, the elementary physics of façades);
• an introduction to construction scales (modules, proportions, dimensioning, thicknesses).

This should enable students to

• take stock: to reference and understand common building systems;
• compare: to identify and differentiate between solutions;
• name: to recognise and know the parts of a constructed whole;
• proportion: to give material expression and order to the various parts of a work;
• plan a project: to draw up and communicate solutions.

info.title: Construction and sustainability II
info.learning_outcomes: See Building technology and materials I.

info.title: Construction and sustainability III
info.content:
On the basis of the knowledge acquired in the first year, the "Construction" angle divides the building into characteristic and recognisable elements in order to introduce the aspects of typology and detail, which will enable students to reconstitute the building as a structure and expressive whole.

In parallel, the "Materials" angle presents the complemetary tools required for the choice of appropriate projects.

The course thus favours the acquisition of a creative construction method as a component of a coherent architectural language.

It therefore teaches scientific and technical knowledge that will enable students to take acts of construction into account in a rational, hierarchised and concrete way, thus providing them with the resources necessary to introduce the factor of "materialisation" into architectural projects while being aware of whole gamut of their complexity.

At the same time, this specific knowledge is placed in an overall philosophy of architecture and within the framework of reflections on history and doctrine (construction culture), just as it would be in the course of the development of a project (construction project).
info.learning_outcomes:
The courses offered under this title focus as much on the technical validity of the project as on the acquisition of a technical culture and the ability to master the logics of construction.

The course thus leads students to

• develop a rational understanding of common and complex forms of construction;

• take account of construction as a step in a project: the ability to project-manage a technically viable architecture with a judicious use of materials and technical processes, together with a mastery of the scales of construction;

• reflect on the construction opportunities of architectural expression in a well-argued manner.

info.title: Construction and sustainability VII
info.content:
The course series will incorporate a theoretical introduction to the history of construction technology and conservation project design.

Relations between materiality and heritage value in both exceptional and more mundane buildings will also be analysed, alongside restoration or adaptation of twentieth-century buildings and an introduction to nineteenth-century and rural heritage.

There will be an introduction to research methods and sources for monograph studies to enable participants to achieve the standard of analytical work required for successful completion.
info.learning_outcomes:
The course has two aims. To begin with, it will trace the evolution of the constructional systems characteristic of C20th architecture, dealing with key notions such as new materials, industrialisation of the building sector and how it transformed the process of building, and the artificial control of building services and comfort. This multidisciplinary knowledge calls for both historical research and detailed consideration of materials technology and construction practice as well as economic and environmental aspects.

Critical-historical research and material analysis, in terms of the specific constructional identity of C20 architecture, demand ad hoc preservation strategies, drawing on specific types of expertise . Creating design tools - for both theory and practice - that take account of the particular issues surrounding modern heritage conservation, is the second major objective of the course.

info.title: Contemporary ethical issues : the engineer in society I
info.exam_form_detail: Sketch of subject, readings reviews, case-study, presentation, final report.
info.content:
Master's degree students are approaching to their professional activity and to the responsibilities that are associated with it. If students look forward to this achievement, they might also worry about future tasks that exceed the specific skills they have acquired during their studies. The Direction of the EPFL has introduced the SHS Programme in order to train students to comply with these « human » dimensions of their professional activity.

This course aims at developing such skills by means of case-study decisions that students might face in their future practice : students are encouraged to integrate ethical reasoning into decisions concerning the « human » dimension of their professional activity.
Students choose, in agreement with the teachers, an ethical case that will be the subjet of their research project. The subject of choice should deal with a contemporary ethical issue.
The research work that will be undertaken during the course includes :
1) the elaboration of the research question, from an ethical point of view ;
2) the clarification of the « ethical » problem at stake, as well as the assessment of the « ethical » implications that will be discussed in the research project ;
3) the development of an ethical discussion on the problem.
In order to achieve their research, students will be asked to realize some intermediate tasks (e.g. readings reviews). The teachers will provide regular monitoring of students' work, including feedbacks and suggestions to facilitate the successful accomplishement of the research project.
Since students are likely to work in teams in their future professional activity, working in groups is strongly recommended, although not mandatory.
info.learning_outcomes:
At the end of the course the student will be able to :
1. identify the ethical questions at stake in a practical problem that an engineer might face ;
2. recognize the normative issues which are controversial ;
3. outline the controversy and relate it to the choices of actors involved ;
4. use ethical concepts to make his/her own assessment, and develop an argument that considers (and answers to) the main objections that might be raised against it.
The main objective of the course is that the student develops argumentative skills in ethics, and is able to show that the decision he would make is grounded on shared and ethically acceptable reasons.
info.keywords: case-study, engineer, ethics, responsibility, society.
info.type_of_teaching:
Teaching methods include :
a) an introduction to methodological approaches in ethics, aimed at providing students with the concepts and methods of reasoning necessary to develop their re-search project ;
b) regular monitoring of students' work through the discussion of problems that they encounter in their research, thus encouraging a collective learning ;
c) time available to students to accomplish their research.
Students have to comply with the course calendar and to deliver a report on their research project on a fixed date. The report has to be written following the teachers' instructions.

info.title: Continuum mechanics
info.prerequisite_for: Rheology, Transfer phenomena, Strength of materials, Materials modelling
info.content:
• From the atomistic to the continuous scale
• Scalar, vector and tensor fields. Vectorial and tensorial calculus and operators
• Strain and stress tensors
• Conservation laws
• State and constitutive equations
• Boundary conditions
• Diffusion-convection
• Solid deformation
• Fluid flow
info.prior_knowledge: Analysis I and II, Linear algebra, General Physics I and II
info.learning_outcomes:
Although materials are made of atoms, grains and phases, it is very common to treat them as continuous media at the macroscopic scale. For that purpose, one has to first introduce the concepts of fields (density, speed, enthalpy, strains, stresses, etc), before writing corresponding conservation equations. Completed by constitutive equations, these equations are solved in a restrained domain with appropriate boundary conditions.
In a first part, this course describes the transition from the atomistic to the macroscopic continuous scale. Then, it introduces the main fields, with vector/tensor calculus and operators. An important part of the course is dedicated to the definition of the strain and stress tensors. Conservation equations, state equations and boundary conditions are then specified. Various situations are finally treated more specifically: fluid flow, solid deformation, diffusion-convection of heat and solute. All these aspects are then further detailed in courses taught during the 4th semester.

info.title: Corporate governance
info.exam_form_detail: Final paper. Presentation by the students.
info.content:
This course will address corporate governance from an organizational and institutional point of view: it will illustrate how corporate governance has evolved over time and will cover both theory and relevant practices. In terms of content, the course will:

- highlight the main issues of corporate governance (e.g., the relationships between the owners, the board, and firm management, and the relationships between the company and its major stakeholders;

- provide concrete examples of "good" and "bad" corporate governance;

- outline key principles of corporate governance;

- present the main tools for assessing corporate governance practices;

- discuss the relevant theories underlying corporate governance practices (e.g., theories of organizations, institutions, governance, organizational behavior, leadership, new institutional economics, power, and agency.
info.learning_outcomes:
The purpose of this course is to offer engineers an appreciation of the importance, an understanding of the foundations, the mechanisms, the evolution, as well as the main assessment tools of corporate governance.

Good corporate governance is an indispensable ingredient of any successful corporation or organization for that matter, be it for established firms or start-ups. As a matter of fact, it is today generally admitted that there exists a relationship between governance practices and corporate performance. As a consequence, increasing attention is being paid to questions of how firms - and all other organizations for that matter - are being "governed" and how they relate to shareholders in particular and to stakeholders in general. The course addresses this broad issue.

info.title: Corporate strategy
info.exam_form_detail: Constructive class participation, case analysis/group presentation, exam/quizzes
info.content:
The course deals both with strategy formulation and implementation for objective economic results. It combines theory and practice.

First, a framework for policy formulation is established through exposure to different concepts and processes.

Second, the role of the chief executive and the senior managers is analyzed to establish a more realistic description of the required integrated duties and capabilities as well as values which lead strategy as a dynamic process.

Third, the function of organizations is examined both as static and dynamic expressions of the major mechanism for implementing strategy.

Finally, different contexts (applications) of strategy are examined to link theory to practice.
info.learning_outcomes:
• To develop an understanding of the strategic process by (a) studying and forecasting the external environment of the firm (b) assessing the present and expected enterprise strengths and weaknesses (c) setting enterprise goals (d) formulating and implementing plans to achieve these strategic goals, and (e) evaluate performance and progress toward strategic objectives.

• To develop decision-making skills from a top management perspective.

• To understand the integration of operating objectives and decisions within the enterprise strategy.

• To use the tools and concepts of strategic management.

info.title: Design and dimensioning of Timber structures
info.content:
The first part is dedicated to wood material. In particular, attention is given to the macro/micro structure of wood, its physical and mechanical properties including hygroscopicity, anisotropic behavior and creep.

The second part introduces the dimensioning bases for simple structural timber elements. The different kinds of actions, the limit states, the establishment and verification of safety conditions are presented. The assemblies and connectors used in timber construction are described in detail. The presentation follows the prevailing Swiss standard SIA 265.


In the last part, some constructive and protective aspects of current timber structures are approached. In particular, the following topics are presented: fire resistance, concrete-wood structures, Physics and acoustics of buildings, the principles of triangulation and stabilization.
