info.title: Design technologies for integrated systems
info.content:
Hardware compilation is the process of transforming specialized hardware description languages into circuit descriptions, which are iteratively refined, detailed and optimized. The course will present the most outstanding features of hardware compilation, as well as the techniques for optimizing logic representations and networks. The course gives a novel, uptodate view of digital circuit design. Practical sessions will teach students the use of current design tools.

Syllabus
1) Modeling languages and specification formalisms;
2) High-level synthesis and optimization methods (scheduling, binding, data-path and control synthesis);
3) Representation and optimization of combinational logic functions (encoding problems, binary decision diagrams);
4) Representation and optimization of multiple-level networks (algebraic and Boolean methods, "don't care" set computation, timing verification and optimization);
5) Modeling and optimization of sequential functions and networks (retiming);
6) Semicustom libraries and library binding.

info.title: Discretization methods in fluids
info.content:
This course provides an introduction to discretization methods used for numerical flow simulation.
It begins with a presentation of the theoretical basis for partial differential equations (adimensionalization, linearization, mathematical classification). Following a unified presentation of classical methods (finite element, finite volume, finite differences), the finite difference method is discussed in detail to illustrate the basic concepts. Through the study of simplified mono-dimensional, steady and unsteady problems, the discrete equations are analyzed in terms of accuracy and stability, which are essential for assessing the consistency of numerical solutions with respect to physical reality. These approaches are then extended to treat multi-dimensional problems. In order to solve the discrete equations, methods for solving (linear and nonlinear) systems of algebraic equations are presented with emphasis on their domain of application and computational complexity.
The finite volume method and mesh generation techniques are subsequently presented to illustrate more applied concepts directly related to fluid mechanics.
Laboratories based on the use of Matlab exercises illustrate the theoretical concepts and provide an understanding of the implementation and use of the algorithms presented. They also serve as the indispensable basis for undertaking the mini-project application.
info.prior_knowledge:
• Linear algebra
• Analysis / Numerical analysis
• Continuum mechanics
• Fluid mechanics
info.learning_outcomes:
Domain Skills:
• Describe different methods used to discretize differential equations, such as finite differences, finite elements, finite volumes, lattice Boltzmann, SPH, AH30
• Evaluate numerical accuracy as a function of the choice of simulation parameters, AH28
• Analyse numerical solutions and identify any inconsistencies with respect to physical reality; understand and apply the concepts of verification and validation, AH29
• Determine the optimal mesh generation technique to apply for the numerical simulation of the flow in a given geometry, AH31
• Understand the basics of computer programming; develop a (simple) structured software using a programming language / environment such as C, Fortran or Matlab, AH40
Transversal skills:
• Write a scientific or technical report, T6
• Document and communicate a project, T12
info.keywords: Numerical simulation, Fluid mechanics, Partial differential equations, Finite difference and finite volume methods

info.title: Distributed information systems
info.prior_knowledge: Bases de données relationnelles or Introduction to information systems
info.content:

Semistructured Data Management: Semistructured data models, Schema extraction and indexing, Semantic Web;
Information Retrieval: Text indexing, Standard information retrieval, Web search engines
Data Mining: Association Rule Mining, Classification, Clustering
info.learning_outcomes:
The lecture gives an overview of key problems in Web-based and mobile information management.
It introduces in detail a selection of characteristic approaches, both from practice and research, and thus creates awareness for the specific challenges in distributed information management and typical solutions.
The students will be able to identify the different problem classes in distributed information management (e.g. mobile data management) and corresponding techniques for solving them (e.g. indexing structures), to understand various standard methods in distributed information management (e.g. vector space information retrieval) and to apply these methods to (simple) practical problems.
We proceed at increasing levels of abstraction. We start from the physical aspects of managing distributed and mobile data (distribution, indexing). Then we introduce into methods for managing the logical structure of Web documents (semistructured data). Finally, we introduce basic methods for dealing with the semantics of documents and data, both for search (information retrieval) and for the extraction of new information (data mining).

info.title: Dynamics of mechanical systems
info.content: Starting from the strong form associated to the problem of linear three-dimensional elastodynamics, the corresponding integral formulation and the weak form are first developed. Based upon the finite element method, the approach focuses on the development of the elemental stiffness, mass, damping, Coriolis and spin and centrifugal stiffness matrices of rotating or non-rotating, conservative or dissipative, systems. Three-dimensional solid and thin to moderately thick shell finite elements are then developed. The possible numerical problems (shear locking, hourglass modes, etc) are discussed and solutions for circumventing these difficulties are presented. In a second part, the course addresses numerically the free motion (modal analysis) of conservative structures modelled with a large number of degrees of freedom and the subspace iteration method, well adapted to this problem, is described and discussed. Finally, the forced motion (time response) of damped structures discretised with a large number of degrees of freedom is studied and the methods of Newmark, powerful for the time response by modal superposition, are presented.

info.title: Ecotoxicology
info.content:
This course focuses on basic concepts in ecotoxicology and mechanistic consideration for risk assessment. Topics include:
• Source and behavior of chemicals in the environment
• Bioavailability
• Organisms and biological test protocols
• Quantification of biological effects
• Toxicokinetics (Processes of internal distribution, metabolism and excretion)
• Toxicodyamics (Processes leading to effects in organisms)
• Linking effects from molecular to ecosystem response
• Concepts of dealing with chemical mixtures, multiple stressors and organisms
• Environmental risk assessment

info.learning_outcomes: Ecotoxicology aims to understand the impact of chemicals and nanoparticles on organisms in the environment with a particular focus on population-, community- and ecosystem effects. Mechanistic understanding requires consideration of physico-chemical properties of the stressors as well as linking biological effects from the molecular and cellular level to higher levels of biological organization. The ultimate goal is to be able to predict stressor-organism interactions in order to protect the respective environment and also human health
info.type_of_teaching: Lecture and exercises. Exercises focus on practical issues, such as estimation of exposure based on knowledge on chemical caracteristics and use of publicly available databases.

info.title: Electromagnetic compatibility
info.content:
1. EMC concept : Source of EM disturbances, victims, coupling path. Incompatibility problems and hierarchy of responsibilities.
2. Coupling Modes : Galvanic, inductive, capacitive, radiation. Calculation methods. Definition of and methods of measuring and calculating transfer impedance.
3. Low Frequency coupling models : Inductive and capacitive coupling. Equivalent coupling circuit. Determination of mutual capacitance and inductance. Methods for reducing interferences. Shielded and twisted cables
4. Transmission line coupling models : Transmission line parameters. Source term representation. Time-domain and frequency-domain solution of coupling equations. Coupling to shielded cables.
5. Electrosatic discharge : Causes, effects and protection methods.
6. EMC in electronic circuits : Grounding. Radiation of digital circuits. Protective measures
7. Shielding : Perfect shield. Field penetration. Shielding effectiveness. Shielding materials. Static field shielding. Shielding continuity. Apertures.
8. EMC in telecommunications. Biological effects of electromagnetic fields.
9. Lightning electromagnetic effects : Lightning phenomena. Different categories of lightning discharge. Cloud-to-ground lightning discharge. Direct and indirect effects of lightning.

By the end of the course the students will have a good understanding of a general EMC problem between a source of EM disturbance and a perturbed system; they will be able to find potential sources of EM pollution in a given environment; and to choose an optimal protection technique based on theoretical and practical studies.

The mecanism of antenna radiation and the elementary radiating source. Typical antenna parameters: impedance, radiation pattern, gain, directivity, efficiency, polarisation, frequency band, noise temperature. Some specific antennas. Introduction to array theory.

info.prerequisite_for: Microwaves and optics transmission, Telecommunications, Mobile communication orientation, Radiation and antennas, Propagation, Audio
info.content:
1) Stationary electric fields
Static charges and electric fields. Vector calculus and equations of Electrostatics. The concepts of potential, voltage and capacity. Energy of electrostatic fields. Conductors and dielectrics. Thee concept of resistance. Perfect electric conductors and their screening properties.
2) Stationary magnetic fields
Steady currents (DC) and magnetic fields. Vector calculus and the equations of Magnetostatics. Energy of magnetostatic fields. Perfect magnetic conductors.

info.title: Electrotechnics II
info.prerequisite_for: All courses of the Electrical and Electronic Engineering Section
info.content:
Electrical circuits basics
Voltage and current sources. Resistance, capacitance and inductance. Kirchhoff laws. Combination of circuit elements. Voltage/current dividers. Source substitution. Fondamental theorems : Thévenin, Norton, power transfer, superposition.
Circuit analysis in sinusoidal steady-state regime
Importance of sinusoidal regime. Response of a linear circuit to a sinusoidal excitation. Phasors and complex analysis. Complexe impedance and admittance. Network of impedances. Phasor representation in complex plane. Bode diagram. Thévenin and Norton theorems in sinusoidal regime. Instantaneous power. Active, reactive and apparent power. Power factor.
Symmetrical three-phase systems
Definitions. Three-phase systems in electrical power transmission and distribution. Symmetrical three-phase systems. Simple and line voltages. Phase voltage and current. Power in three-phase systems. Star and delta connections. Star-delta conversions.
Unsymmetrical three-phase systems
Symmetrical voltage sources and unsymmetrical loads. Analysis of a star-connected load. Analysis of a delta-connected load.
Transient analysis
Definitions. Response to unit-step excitations. Initial conditions. Transient analysis of simple circuits. Time constants. Transient and steady-state responses of a circuit.
info.library_recomm: • "Introduction à l'électrotechnique / par Frédéric de Coulon et Marcel Jufer". Year:2001. ISBN:2-88074-041-X
info.learning_outcomes:
Students will be able to analyze basic linear circuits. They will learn to
apply phasor theory based on complex numbers to analyze linear circuits
in sinusoidal regime. They will also learn to analyze symmetrical and
unsymmetrical three-phase systems. Finally, they will be able to perform
a transient analysis of basic electrical circuits.
info.type_of_teaching: Ex cathedra lectures. Exercises and labs.

info.title: Electrotechniques
info.content:
Electrical circuits
Voltage and current sources, resistance, inductance and capacitor. DC circuit. Kirchhoff laws. Combination of circuit elements. Fundamental theorems: Thevenin, Norton, power transfer, superposition.

Single-phase circuits in sinusoidal steady-state regime
Principle of voltage generation. Phasors and complex analysis. Complex impedances and admittances. Sinusoidal steady-state regime. Instantaneous power. Active, reactive and apparent powers. Power factor. Real sources. Thevenin and Norton theorems in sinusoidal regime.

Multi-phase systems
Definitions. Symmetrical three-phase systems. Simple and line voltages. Star and delta connections. Power in three-phase systems. Star-delta conversions. Three-phase systems with unsymmetrical star and delta-connected loads.
Electric and magnetic circuits
Magnetic field intensity and magnetic induction. Ampere law. Flux, permeances, inductances. Charge and electric field. Induction law. Linked circuits.

Transient analysis
Definitions. Response to unit-step excitations. Transient analysis of simple circuits. Time constants. Transient and steady-state responses of a circuit.
info.learning_outcomes: Students will be able to analyze basic linear circuits. They will learn to apply phasor theory based on complex numbers to analyze single-phase systems as well as symmetrical and unsymmetrical three-phase systems in sinusoidal regime. They will also be able to perform a transient analysis of basic linear circuits.

info.title: Elements of urban and territorial analysis I
info.content:
Presentation of various types of analysis in order to understand the issues of scales, and to clarify the articulations between architecture, the city and the territory.
Among these types of analysis, drawing will occupy a central position - drawing considered as a system of representation, as a moment of discovery and as a construction of knowledge.
info.learning_outcomes:
"Faculty to create is never given to us all alone. It always goes hand in hand with the gift of observation." Igor Stravinsky.

This course prepares to the spatial analysis of urban and territorial situations. It establishes a corpus of references and presents tools for observations and analysis. It presents theoretical frameworks (for example: modernity) and themes (for example: the relations between urban structures and monuments) which will be developed in the following years. It proposes possible paths between the knowledge given by the analysis, and the intuitions on which the projects can develop.


Competence and knowledge to be acquired

At the end of the course, the student will understand
• the phenomenon of permanence and question of transformations,
• the ways by which topography and the infrastructures affect urban structures,
• the articulations of local and territorial scales,
• the characteristics of various types of urban fabrics and public spaces.
He (she) will have a basic knowledge of local and international references which establish a cultural framework of the contemporary urban situations.
He will be able to evaluate the interests and the limits of various means of analysis by the development of specific analysis of a particular place.

info.title: Emotions, self and social cognition I
info.exam_form_detail: Contrôle continu, specifics announced at the beginning of the course
info.content:
We like to think that we are mainly under the control of our actions, our thoughts, and our wills. Yet, the self is an emotional self as well reacting upon its bodily signals and thoughts, frequently in interaction with its current and previous environment. We are thus not simply an individual self, but also a social self. The problematic and scientific study of these topics will be presented in the first part of the course, after having provided basic knowledge on scientific and empirical methods common to cognitive psychology, and thus essential to follow the content of the later course.
At the same time, students will start to elaborate on study ideas and questions that will determine their research activates during the remaining course. In particular, individual research projects will be performed in groups of 2-3 students. The specific research questions will be developed and elaborated for research questions / topics provided for this course. After having decided on a hypothesis, students will develop their method, test participants (data collection), treat the data for statistical analysis, write a scientific report.
info.learning_outcomes:
Learn how to run an empirical study using a scientific approach in cognitive psychology.
Elaborate a study hypothesis based on the existent literature.
Select a paradigm that is suitable to test your hypothesis.
Test your hypothesis
Learn empirical and statistical means to analyse whether your hypothesis is likely to be true or false.
Learn how to critically discuss your findings
Learn to write a scientific report (basic structure also to be found in published scientific reports).
info.keywords: self and others, agency, embodiment, social self, social cognition, rationality, decision making, reasoning

info.title: Energy and society I
info.content:
Industrial societies are concerned about the limits of economic growth, particularly because of their dependence on scarce natural resources such as fossil fuels. Currently, this questioning is focused on fears of disasters caused by global warming due to human activities. As the consumption of fossil fuels is a major source of CO2 emissions, a global economic strategy is the fossil fuels' abandonment and the adoption of other energy sources.

We propose to examine and discuss some aspects of this strategy by using methods and knowledge developed by technical, natural and social sciences, in particular economics.
info.learning_outcomes: Understand some key issues related to energy, environment and climate change by means of case studies, on the basis of the tools of analysis provided by economics and social sciences, from a pluridisciplinary point of view.
info.type_of_teaching: Students have to follow the courses during the first term as well as to define and complete group projects in a pluridisciplinary context. Modalities and timing will be specified at the beginning of the year.

info.title: Engines and fuel cells
info.exam_form_detail: Draw 1 question each from engines and from fuel cells, prepare for 30 min. Oral defense 15 min each for engines and for fuel cells.
info.content:
Operation principles, Mechanical (kinematics, dynamics) and thermodynamic principles (ideal cycles), Diesel and spark ignition engines (combustion process, load regulation, noise analysis and prevention, electronics regulation, supercharging), Characterization of combustion gases, pollutant formation, Means and methods of emissions reduction, Modeling (cycle modeling, time dependant combustion, sub-systems modeling), New concepts: hybrids systems, downsizing, direct injection, discussion.
Construction and architecture of fuel cell families, for application at ambient and high temperature. Operating principles, thermodynamics and kinetics. Advantages and challenges, highlighting the efficiency (electrical, cogeneration, part-load). Fuel choice and fuel treatment (hydrogen, hydrocarbons). Aspects of modeling in fuel cells. Exercices with numerical exemples.

info.title: Enterprise and service-oriented architecture
info.content:
1) Business Part (5 weeks) :practical experimentation and theoretical understanding of the key business processes of a manufacturing company : sale, development, planning, quality management and finance.
2) Business / IT Part (7 weeks) :specification of customer service system. Taught techniques : interviews, root cause analysis, analysis/design of the services provided by the company and by the IT department.
3) IT part (2 weeks) :implementation - using visual programming - of an IT system prototype. Overview of the service-oriented architecture (bpmn, wsdl, bpel) and of enterprise architecture (Zachman, TOGAF).
info.learning_outcomes:
The IT industry is going through a major shift with the notion of services. Engineers need to focus mainly on the service provided to the business and less on its implementation. In this course you will learn how to specify a hierarchy of services for a company, from the business service provided to the end customer to the IT service that prowers the business service. The skills taught in this course are essential if you are interested to become a consultant, an IT project manager, or need to specify IT system requirements.

In this course, you will : (1) Manage a (simulated) manufacturing company. (2) Specify the required business service and define the role of IT in providing this service. (3) Implement a prototype of the IT service.

In this course, we teach the theory only after the practical experimentation. Without your active participation in the experimentation there will be no learning! This course mainly focuses on the business and IT strategies. No traditional programming is done in this course!

info.title: Entrepreneurship & new venture strategy
info.content:
• Theoretical Foundations / Innovation and Industry Evolution
• Opportunity Identification / Sources of Innovation
• Entry Strategy, Competitive Advantage and Uncertainty / Business Models / Judo Strategy
• Entrepreneurial Marketing and Technology Commercialization II
• Discovery Driven Planning / Basics of business planning
• Issues in Building a New Venture Team / Growth and Scalability of Organizations
• Raising Capital / The Economics of Venture Capital Financing
• Harvesting the Rewards / Dealing with Failure
info.learning_outcomes:
This class is the foundation course in Entrepreneurial Management. The purpose of this course is to explore new venture creation by adopting a process perspective - from opportunity recognition to establishing a successful new firm - and by studying the challenges of entrepreneurship from multiple perspectives, i.e. from various functional perspectives such as finance, managerial economics and marketing, as well as from the perspective of various key constituents involved in new venture creation (e.g., venture capitalists). In this course, a new venture is defined as an innovative start-up firm which has a high potential for growth and value generation.
The course will offer a thorough theoretical understanding of new venture creation combined with practical techniques and methods for analyzing and evaluating business opportunities, crafting growth-oriented strategies and developing creative approaches to commercialization. The class will prepare students to work as key employees in new ventures, to pursue careers as autono¬mous entrepreneurs, careers as intrapreneurs and careers in the start-up community.


The five main pedagogical objectives of this course are:
• Understand the challenges of new venture creation in a comprehensive, integrative way
• Experience the early stages of the entrepreneurial process by working on a business project proposal
• Sharpen your ability to analyze and evaluate new venture opportunities
• Be able to write and present a convincing business project proposal
• Develop an "entrepreneurial mindset"
info.keywords: Entrepreneurship, New Firms, Technology Commercialization

info.title: Entrepreneurship Laboratory (e-lab)
info.exam_form_detail: A project paper and formal exams
info.content:
High-tech entrepreneurship has become a major topic of innovation thanks to the value creation of companies such as Microsoft, Intel, Genentech, Apple or Google. Such companies did not exist forty years ago and some of them are merely ten years old. Still, high growth remains somehow a mystery which could not be really replicated (with only a few exceptions) outside of Silicon Valley. Such an exceptional phenomenon will be studied not only through case studies but also through real live cases.

The high failure rate of start-up growth is an indication that even in Silicon Valley entrepreneurship remains a difficult process, not to say that it is nearly impossible to master. No theory has been able to predict the outcome of entrepreneurial ventures and it is not even clear that practice and experience really help in building successful start-ups. Therefore, the only way to better understand startup dynamics is to experience them in real cases. EFPL is surrounded by a higher than average high-tech start-ups, particularly at the Science Park (PSE) and close by Garage.

Students will be given an opportunity to work with entrepreneurs on challenges they face in the start-up growth. Given the limited timeframe, it will not be possible to have a complete overview of the challenges an entrepreneur faces, but the objective would be that the students learn as much as possible from such a situation. Because all start-ups are different however, a large part of the course will be to complement the real case with other case studies so that the students learn as much as possible.

info.title: Environmental geovisualization
info.content: The geovisualization approach will mainly be demonstrated in the context of research activities carried out at the Institute of Environmental Engineering (IIE): case studies and data produced by IIE's laboratories will be used for exercices. IIE's professors and scientists will give talks to explain the contribution of geovisualization in their research field. Lab work will consist of geovisualization tasks to be carried out with the help of dedicated GVIS software.
info.library_recomm: • "Exploratory analysis of spatial and temporal data : a systematic approach / Natalia Andrienko, Gennady Andrienko". Year:2008. ISBN:978-3-540-25994-7
info.learning_outcomes:
At the end of lectures and exercices, students shall be able :
- to apply a geovisualization approach to any georeferenced data set;
- to apply GVIS to uncover underlying geographic structures and to detect outliers in any investigated spatial data set;
- to form working hypotheses with standard statistical tools (confirmatory statistics) on the basis of GVIS (exploratory statistics);
- to know how to apply the "Information Seeking Mantra"; or any other systematic way to implement geovisualization.
Goals
- To make students aware of the geographic dimension of (almost) any data set to be analysed or to be processed within environmental sciences and environmental engineering;
- To make students aware that scientific visualization represents a powerful force for perception and understanding;
- To illustrate Exploratory Spatial Data Analysis (ESDA), Scientific Visualization, and Geovisualization's contribution to highlight hidden patterns in the spatial distribution of any environmental variable, to detect relationships between investigated factors or individuals;
- To show that the geovisualization approach is also useful in the context of data management, and decision-making related tasks.

info.title: Existing structures I : Security and durability
info.content:
Engineering of existing structures: Systematic approach, material and societal value, requirements, terminology.
Deterioration of reinforced concrete: Transport phenomena and deterioration mechanisms, carbonation and chloride induced reinforcement corrosion, cracking, freeze-thaw effects, alkali-aggregate reaction, evolution of the condition state and deterioration curves.
Investigations and condition survey: Visual survey, cover concrete empirical characterisation (permeability, thickness, resistivity), electrochemical potential measurement, impact-echo and georadar methods, deformation and force measurements.
Structural safety: Stage-based procedure, structural behaviour, updating of resistance (material properties, resistance models) and actions (permanent loads, traffic loads, climatic actions), models for the structural analysis, accidental actions, probabilistic method application, required safety level.
Surveying: Methodology, inspection methods (visual and by measurements), safety considerations
info.learning_outcomes:
- To acquire a systematic approach for the examination of an existing structure
- To master structural behaviour, the physico-chemical fundamentals and applied mechanics (bridges, buildings)
- To update structural safety verification model data including action and resistance

title: Existing structures I : Security and durability

info.title: Existing structures II : Interventions
info.content:
Maintenance interventions: Planning of rehabilitative interventions (concept and design of rehabilitation measures), intervention validation, maintenance measures adequacy.
Rehabilitation and protection methods: for structures in reinforced concrete (surface protection systems, concrete re-placing, electrochemical methods, inhibitors), steel, timber and masonry.
Additional reinforcement: Glued composite lamellas, external post-tensioning, design, force application (anchorage, deviators), hazard scenarios.
Different aged concrete composite structural elements: Early age and long term behaviour, restrained deformations, risk of cracking, fracture behaviour, improved concrete and steel, ultra-high performance fibre reinforced concrete.
Accidental actions: Options for intervention, cost effectiveness, safety measure adequacy.
Operational measures: Options, monitoring (instrumentation conceptual design, detection reliability and probability, limit values).
Management of structures: Approach and models, life cycle considerations, intervention strategy and program
info.learning_outcomes:
- To master the physico-chemical fundamentals and applied mechanics to existing structures (concrete bridges and buildings)
- To further develop the modelling and evaluation fundamentals of existing structures
- To further develop intervention methods
- To further explore the notion of structural safety

info.title: Finite element method
info.content: Starting from the strong form associated to the problem of the longitudinal deformation in a uniform bar under traction and compression, the corresponding integral formulation and the weak form are first developed. The latter formulation is next discretised by means of the Galerkin method and the finite element method. Typical concepts like shape functions, classes of admissible functions, Hilbert and Sobolev spaces of functions or convergence criteria, necessary for the understanding of the approach, are briefly described, and the discrimination between natural and essential boundary conditions is discussed. The one-dimensional problem is then generalised by introducing various discontinuities (loading, section, material, etc) into the bar and the concept of higher-order finite elements is introduced. Following an approach similar to the one used for the one-dimensional problem, the course then focuses on the two-dimensional boundary-value problem of heat conduction on a surface. The corresponding weak formulation based on a scalar variable (temperature) is then approximated with two-dimensional finite elements. Lagrangian and serendipity, quadrangular and triangular, so-called master elements are developed and used for elaborating two-dimensional arbitrarily shaped finite elements (geometrically deformed finite elements). After a convergence study of the approximated solutions obtained with two-dimensional finite elements, an example of application is fully treated.

info.title: Flexible electronics
info.prior_knowledge: It is useful but not mandatory to have some background or interest in one of the following: Materials and microtechnology; thin-films, microfabrication; semiconductor devices
info.content:
The course is an introduction to flexible electronics. Because of the interdisciplinary nature of the subject, its content includes concepts from many disciplines in engineering (electrical, materials, mechanical, and chemical).

Thin film transistors (TFTs) are the "case study" of the course. TFTs are field-effect transistors. They differ from conventional transistors (where the semiconductor material is the substrate itself) by having their semiconductor material deposited as a thin film onto a carrier substrate. The substrate may be a glass plate, a steel foil or a polymeric membrane.

The course will cover how to design, fabricate and characterise TFTs, and will evaluate how one can implement TFTs to produce compliant electronic circuits. An overview of current industrial and academic applications for mechanically compliant electronics will also be given.

• Be able to explain the operating principles of thin film transistors

info.title: Gender and knowledge
info.content:
Gender : Putting Words on Nature and Culture

Two classes will be devoted to the presentation of useful concepts to grasp the notion of gender as both an object of study and an epistemological point of view. Then, following classes will take the form of an exchange (cf. "cours-séminaire") between teachers and students on the basis of a variety of documents enabling the elaboration of a critical discourse about diverse forms of representation surrounding us: films, TV series, clips, paper articles, reviews of scientific articles by the general press, advertisements, photoshop...
info.learning_outcomes: Introduction to the notion of "gender" as it relates to things and speeches. Studying the implicit and explicit stereotypes structuring our daily material framework and speech habits as they relate to gender. Enabling students to moderate a precise and well-informed debate about gender as distinct from a non-scientific approach based on "common sense". Creating a platform of dialogue between science and literature around the concept of gender which is relevant to all disciplines but which we usually get to know from the different "disciplinarian" angles of each branch.

info.title: Geology
info.content: Introduction: History of geological sciences and their utility for engineers. Planetary geology: The Earth in the Universe, contributions of planetary geology to the comprehension of the Earth and the processes which are occuring on it. History of the Earth: Evolution of the Earth and of life, dating methods. Geophysics: Seismology, gravimetry, magnetism, use of the geothermal energy. Constitutive minerals of rocks: Crystalline structures, main geochemical classes, identification of the most common minerals. Magmatism: tectonic plates, ridge -hot points -orogenic magmatism, corresponding rocks and their properties (plutonic and volcanic rocks), risks related to the volcanic eruptions. Water Cycle: different kinds of water on Earth, Hydrologic cycle, the atmosphere, surface water, groundwater, water resources. Continental Environment: Processes of erosion and deposition, geomorphology, landslides and rock falls, lakes, palustrine, glacial and desert environments. Marine environment: Coastal and abyssal sedimentation processes, biogenic and evaporitic sediments. Interactions between earth sciences and life sciences. Diagenesis: Processes of transformation of sediments in rocks (compaction, cementation, light mineralogical modifications), geology of fossil fuel. Metamorphism: Solid recrystallization of rocks, regional -contact -and dynamo-metamorphism, corresponding rocks and their properties. Tectonics: Stress and strain in rocks, brittle deformations (diaclasis, fractures), ductile deformations (folds). Rocks weathering: Phenomena leading to weathering (mechanical, chemical, mineralogical), rocks sensitive to alteration, consequences for engineers, recommendations.

info.learning_outcomes: The activities of the civil and the environmental engineers are in constant interaction with the earth environment. The course of geology gives to the students an academic view of geosciences and the bases necessary to a well integrated engineering in the context of our planet. The main objective are : -Knowing the geological methods and the geodynamic processes which lead to genesis, deformation and weathering of surficial deposits and rocks. -Studying the nature of the main geological substrates and their properties. -Understanding how the geological conditions influence the activities of the engineer, how they can facilitate them, how they can complicate them. -Making students aware of the external geodynamic evolutions and their consequences on the environment, the geomorphology, the landforms and the territory.

info.title: Going East I
info.exam_form_detail: Exam on gained knowledge (Going East 1) and oral presentation of the research-based written project (Going East 2).
info.content:
The Fall semester («Going East 1») features four modules that each focus on a specific region or country: the Middle East, India, China and Japan. Each module will be introduced by a historic and geopolitic overview to initiate and better understand the local realities. It will be followed by a lecture on specific cultural or artistic expressions of the region or country. Relevant and attractive, these cases studies (architecture, literature, music, movies, social networks, manga) will deepen a particular cultural focus, which in turn will inform understanding of the society as a whole. Finally, a personality from the field (head of a Swiss company, diplomat or scientist with extensive international cooperation) will close this module by sharing their expertise and experience on what it means to live and work abroad and give a practical perspective on other cultures.

Spring semester («Going East 2») consists of tutored projects sessions as agreed with supervisors. Project will focus on themes from lectures of the Fall semester.
info.learning_outcomes:
The Middle East and Asia are considered historic junctions of cultures, languages and religions. Their importance in terms of worldwide exchange - goods, services, peoples, but also, crucially, ideas and technical innovation - is often overlooked.
«Going East» focuses on civilizations and societies, both ancient and present, engaged in deep transformations. Lectures will provide knowledge and tools for a better understanding of the cultures of these regions (the Middle East, India, China and Japan) as preparation for living and working abroad.
The reflexive and constructivist perspective that provides the thread of Going East will reveal the dangers of an uncritical look at non-Western societies and the trap of clichés and stereotypes important to avoid when trying to understand other societies, cultures and subcultures.

Going East 1 is an introductory class to a masters project (3 credits). It will be taught alternately in French and in English. It is open to and recommended for anyone interested in a dialogue with «other» cultures. At the end of the semester, students have two options:

a) Enrol in «Going East 2» in spring 2012 and complete the missing 3 credits by writing a research project in agreement supervisors in CACS.

b) Enrol in the «Minor in Area and Cultural Studies» (http://cdh.epfl.ch/cas). The minor will start in spring 2012 and finish December 2012. Lausanne and Bangalore/Shanghai summer schools are its central programmes. The remaining 3 credits (along the classic lines of the CDH Master Programme) may be obtained via language courses in parallel to the minor, starting in spring 2012 (Mandarin, Hindi or Arabic).
info.keywords: Middle East, China, India, culture, local realities

info.learning_outcomes: Algebraic K-theory, which to any ring R associates a sequence of groups K0R, K1R, K2R,... can be viewed as a theory of linear algebra over an arbitrary ring. info.title: History of architecture I
info.content:
The course follows the chronological path:

Egypt and the genesis of monumental art. Mesopotamia and the glory of the brick. The Minoan World, creator of palaces. Mycenae and the citadel of the Cyclopes. The Aegean world and the origin of Greece; the invention of art for art. Rome and the school of Greece. Modernity and universality of the imperial programs. From Constantine to Byzantium, the propagation of the heritage. The early Christian century and the preservation of the knowledge. The monumental Renaissance of the Capetian dynasty. The gothic century and daring innovation without limits.

The course will concentrate mainly on the building techniques and not on the evolution of styles. However construction programs will be discussed according to their undertaking of building sites and their use of fundamental and innovative techniques.

Every period will consider the following aspects:

The creators: the men of power and the architects; their ambitions, their culture, their education and their position in society. The search for the building materials: stone, brick, wood. The transport of the materials: over land, on the rivers, by sea; on sledge, cart and barge. The men on the building sites: their training, their tools, their skills. The erecting of the building: ramps, scaffolding and machines. The skeleton and the finishing off: vertical support, cupola, framework, facing.
info.learning_outcomes:
The building site, beginning with the Egypt at the time of pharaohs up to gothic cathedrals. Materials, tools, machines, manufacturing

The objectives of the course will be the analysis of building sites, from ancient Egypt to the gothic period, the study of the transmission of Greek and Roman knowledge up to the Middle Ages, the understanding of the symbolic and structural functioning of the different monuments.

info.title: History of architecture II
info.content:
The analysis will be about the most significant buildings and about anonymous houses of different urban centres, the master pieces of Brunelleschi, Michelozzo, Rossel-lino, Giuliano da Maiano, Giuliano da Sangallo, Cronaca in Florence and in other Tuscan cities, the master pieces of Alberti, Laurana, Francesco di Giorgio Martini in Mantova, Urbino and Siena, from Filarete, Amadeo, Bramante in Milano, Bergamo, Pavia, from Bon, Gambello, Codussi, Lombardo in Venezia, from Fioravanti, Portigiani, Nuti in Bologna and Cesena, from Sagrera and Carnalivari in Napoli and in Sicilia.

The lessons will concentrate on the systems of construction, the materials and the structures: The cutting of the stone for the building of the walls, arches, architraves, columns; the techniques of the facing in Venezia; the main structural figures "à l'antique" in Rome; the vaults and the cupolas "en agrégat"; the moulded ornaments and the ornaments in "papier mâché"; the works of metal fusion; the geometries and innovative techniques of the military architecture; the rules of art to build codified in the De Re Aedificatoria of Alberti, in the papers of Filarete and di Giorgio Martini, in the exercise books of da Sangallo, to the studies of da Vinci on the cracks of buildings and resistance of structure.
info.learning_outcomes:
Principles and construction of the architecture of the Quattrocento

Is it possible to destroy the ideological heritage of the XIX century, which, untill today, forms our idea of the "Renaissance"? It is around this question that the course will analyse the architecture of the Quattrocento in Italy, all the types of buildings - churches, monasteries, chapels, public and private palaces, houses, hospitals, urban fortresses, castles, bridges - especially the study of the techniques, structures and materials, in order to clarify without prejudice the relations between the logic of construction and the "modern" forms and the forms "à l'antique".

info.title: History of architecture III
info.content: The architectures of Bramante, Raffaello, Giulio Romano, Antonio da Sangallo "Le Jeune", Baldassarre Peruzzi, Jacopo Sansovino, Michele Sanmicheli, Andrea Palladio and I quattro libri dell'architettura, Michelangelo, Vignola and the "Traité sur les ordres". The taking measurements of the architectures of the antiquity. Fini and "non finito", architecture "ruinée". Techniques, structures, materials, finishes. Building sites and the organization of the work.
info.learning_outcomes:
Construction, architectures, theories of the "Cinquecento"

This course introduces the students to the knowledge of Italian architectures of the "Haute Renaissance" by providing them with the tools to analyze them as well as to understand their historical reasons and evaluate their qualities, through the study of a few examples, thus contributing to develop the students'ability to "read" architecture. The architectures will be studied in such a way to encourage the students to question the reasons of building them in a definite time and place, the objective of the customer, the builder and the architect, the influence of the architect's conceptions had on the realisations of the architectures, why the spaces and structures have been conceived that way, why the functions have been distributed that way, how and why the various materials and techniques have been chosen, what are the connection between an architecture and its physical location, how it is influenced by the conditions it is viewed, what are its connections with architectures of the past or of the same period with similar functions, etc. These various questions should make the students able to consider the interconnections between several aspects.

info.title: History of architecture IV
info.content:
Architecture and construction in France, 16th century

The works of De l'Orme, Lescot, Androuet du Cerceau, Serlio. Doctors on the building site, from Savot to Gallaccini. Galileo, Leibnitz, De la Hire: towards a new science of building. Theory and practice of the cutting of stones : Desargues, Bosse, Jousse, Derand. New monumental orders, from Bernini to Wren. Beyond the orders: Borromini, Guarini. The construction in the colonnade of the Louvre: technical and theoretical virtuosities of Blondel, Le Vau, Perrault. Resistance tests of materials and the crisis of the vitruvian theory of architecture. The building site of the Panthéon in Paris, from Soufflot to Rondelet. Patte and the French technical inventions. Lodoli and the "rigoristi" of Venice: theoretical fundamentals for an architecture of materials. Laugier and the "petite cabane rustique".
info.learning_outcomes:
From Galileo to Lodoli: towards the perfect construction

The course tries to reread the architecture of the 16th and 17th centuries in the light of the building-up of the different forms of scientific knowledge that contributed to create the foundations of a utopian perfect construction.

info.title: History of architecture V
info.content:
From the wall "ordonnancé" of Schinkel to the "waandarchitectuur" of Berlage

Schinkel and Labrouste: wall and metal structure. Quatremère de Quincy, Hittorff, Semper: from the polychromie in the antiquity to the "Prinzip der Verkleidung". Viollet-le-Duc and the truth of structure, material and program. Castiron construction in New York. From Le Baron Jenney to Sullivan: research on the features of the skyscraper. Wright and the myth of space. Wagner, Hoffmann, Olbrich, Plecnik, Loos: bordered surface or without suture. Gaudì and the architecture of small chains. Berlage and the "waandarchitectuur".
info.learning_outcomes:
Space, structure, envelope in the architectures of the 19th and 20th centuries.

The course proposes to develop the capacity of the students to recognize and to interpret the cultural and constructive significations of each element of a work, its arrangement and its relationships in the general organism, in the context of a contemporary architecture marked by the assertion of two leading theoretical systems, the one of Semper and the one of Viollet-le-Duc, as well as of the discontinuous shape of the iron framework or of the reinforced concrete.

info.title: History of architecture VI
info.content:
From the "ossature-remplissage" of Perret to the hollow structure of Kahn.

From Behrens to Taut: Symbol and structure. From Baudot and Sauvage: shapes "flamboyantes" of the structure. From the "Cite Industrielle" to the "Ville Contemporaine": cities of the future in reinforced concrete. Futurism, constructivism, De Stijl. Perret: order and truth of reinforced concrete. Le Corbusier: from the framework "Dom-ino" to the "espace indicible". Mies van der Rohe: Search for the perfect structure. Terragni: sculptural framework and wall. Kahn and the hollow structure.
info.learning_outcomes: See History of architecture V.

info.title: History of architecture VII
info.content:
Radical Architectures: from the Archizoom to Rem Koolhaas/OMA
In the first part of the course, we will analyze the works of Archizoom. The Art Pop and Kitsch designs. The Dream Beds and the Gazebos, The architectural projects up to the No-Stop City.

In the second part of the course, we will analyze the works of Koolhaas/OMA : The studies and projects of the Architectural Association School of Architecture of London: "Berlin Wall as Architecture", "Exodus, or The Voluntary Prisoners of Architecture". Dalì's paranoiac-critic method. Projects and theories during the stay in New York and the foundation of the Office for Metropolitan Architecture. The myth of the Floating Swimming Pool and Leonidov. The teaching at the AA School of Architecture and the criterion of the Tektonik. The Culture of Congestion in Delirious New York. The New Sobriety from OMA against the Post-Modernism of Krier and the Contextualism of Rowe. The project for Rotterdam, Arnhem and Paris in the Danstheater and at the villa Dall'Ava: "modernité vernaculaire", "congestion invisible" and forms of Dutch Manhattanism. The century of the "merveilles", the Kunsthal at Grand Palais of Lille, at the Educatorium, at the villa in Floirac. Typical Plan, Bigness, Generic City: principles for a theory. Projects in Tours: on search of the "composite stability". Polyedric shapeless solids or functional graphs, from McCormick Tribune Campus Centre to the Seatle Public Library. Junkspace and patents.
info.learning_outcomes:
Radical Architectures - Vitruvius and Missler Software
The first semester concentrates on the study of the works of Archizoom and Koolhaas/OMA; the second on the mathematics of Vitruvius'De Architectura viewed through the new version TS7 of Missler Software.

info.title: History of architecture VIII
info.content:
The basic concept of intertextuality questions the traceability of ideas, themes and forms in architecture and considers the "sources" or "influences" not only as granted but also as agents of a creative work. With the intertextual approach, a particular role is given to "genetic" analysis - and critics -, hence to the study of the projecting choices which are gradually made according to external stimuli or influences and, above all, for reasons of internal coherence. These choices are very important to define the meaning of the work.

Based on the indications found in architectural criticism and historiography, from the second half of the 20th century onwards, we will introduce concepts that have had a decisive and somewhat subliminal on the projecting practice of the 20th century. These concepts are mainly: 'Raumgestaltung' (or space design), that architects and historians have sometimes considered as the very essence of architecture; architectonic as the expressive dimension (demonstrated or not) of the "raw" technical constructional element, of the "functionality" as an expressive dimension (expressed or denied) of the objective elements of the interface between use and work. We will then try to identify the "figures" that result in the representation conveyed by the above mentioned concepts and to analyze them as "stylistic features".
info.learning_outcomes: The objective of this course is to develop the analytical, critical and interpretational skills of the student regarding the architectural work. Based on several "readings" of projects or realizations, a series of "critical instruments" will be gradually introduced and explained during the course.

info.title: Housing economics
info.content: The course examines the past, recent and predictable evolution of housing in Switzerland, living and ownership modes, the aspirations and financial constraints of households, as well as their housing mobility. The course also examines the low proportion of owner-occupants and the permanent shortage that characterize the Swiss housing market, past and present housing policy, as well as rent regulation. Students thus have an opportunity to address the advantages and barriers of owner-occupation, single-family homes, and habitat in city center and suburbs. Furthermore, they discover the economic challenges for landlords, the constraints they face and the financial and legal context in which they operate. Finally, the course gives students the means to understand the mechanisms of housing demand and supply.

info.learning_outcomes: This course prepares to the analysis of habitats, housing and cities from the economic point of view. At the end of the course, students will be able to assess households' housing needs, their differences and the amounts they are willing to spend for housing, as well as understand the point of view of the landlords and the legal context of housing production. They will understand why some households cannot fulfill their housing aspirations and why the housing stock ends up being allocated as observed.

• Electromagnetics (FEM)
• Heat transfer (FEM)
• Structures and mechanical stress (FEM)
info.learning_outcomes:
The objectives of this course are mainly in the learning of modern techniques for representation and modeling of complex systems, where multidisciplinary aspects are of importance. This course is dedicated in a first approach to learning of modern techniques for representation and modeling of complex systems with the help of Causal Ordering Graphs (COG) and Energetic Macroscopic Representation (EMR).

In a second approach, the lecture will present modern methods for the modeling of local and global phenomena by Finite Element Methods. This will be an introduction for engineers who intend to setup multiphysical modeling, where superposition and interaction between different phenomena of different nature must be taken into account (Electromagnetics, heat transfer, structures and mechanical stress).

This course represents an opportunity for advanced students for discovering diverse and new methods in relation with solving of even more complex problems.

info.title: Hydraulic structures and schemes I
info.prerequisite_for: Hydraulic structures and schemes II, Dams and appurtenant structures, Fluvial hydraulics and river training works, Urban hydrology, Hydraulic and energy networks, Master

info.content:
• Objectives and function of hydraulic schemes: flood protection schemes, hydropower plants, multipurpose schemes (flood protection, energy production, irrigation, navigation, water supply).

• Particularities of hydraulic schemes: protection of nature and environment; key factor for economical development, sustainable development; realisation, monitoring and maintenance, hydraulic calculations.

• Flood protection measures: bed load transport in natural channels, river bank stabilisation, flood retention basin, diversion and management of floods, soil bioengineering.

• Weirs on rivers: layout and selection criteria of type of structures, types and fonctioning of gates. Principles of hydraulic design and construction details of weirs including stability analysis.

• River intakes: choice of type and design cirteria (side, frontal and bottom intake). Management of sediment transport and floating debris. Design and cleaning of trash racks.

• Layout and design of desilting facilities. Constructive details and flushing systems.

• Waterway systems: free surface channel and tunnels, penstocks, pressure tunnels and shafts. Design criteria for optimum alignment and section; hydraulic and construction aspects. Structural design: hydraulic and static interactions. Design of open and covered channels including transient flow conditions (surge waves). Basics of penstocks, steel liners and surge tanks with transient flow conditions (water hammer).

Engineering application by exercices treating practical problems. The course is deepened and completed by optional courses (hydraulic structures and schemes II and dams).

info.title: Hydraulic structures and schemes II
info.content:
• Hydropower plants : types of powerhouses, layout and functioning of the main elements. Design of low, medium and high head schemes. Type of turbines. Pumped-storage power plants.
• Reservoirs: design of volume and problematic of sedimentation.
• Criteria to find the optimum location of a reservoir in a catchment area. Types of dams.
• Intakes in lakes and reservoirs : selection criteria of type, hydraulic design, vortex formation.
• Pressure tunnels and shafts. Types of linings and design of pervious and impervious linings. General design and safety criteria.
• River diversion works : possibilities of river diversion during construction of hydraulic structures. Hydraulic design and construction aspects.
• Bottom outlets: purpose and principal elements of a bottom outlet. Hydraulic design and problems related to hydromechanical structures (gates, etc.) and aeration/air demand.
• Spillways: uncontrolled and gated overflow structures, orifices, chutes and stilling basins. Particularities of high velocity flows (natural and forced air entrainment, cavitation erosion) and energy dissipation (flip Bucket and plunge pool), scouring problems due to high veloicity jets.

With help of dimensional analysis of the Navier-Stokes equations, several fluid models are introduced depending on the dominant physical effects: hydrostatics, capillarity, dissipation or inertia. info.title: Indoor environment quality and energy in buildings
info.content:
Indoor environment quality as observed today in buildings.
The sick building syndrome.
Comfort conditions and inhabitants needs.

How to ensure at a minimum energy cost:

• Thermal comfort?
• Indoor air quality?
• Avoiding moisture and mould problems?
• Good lighting?
• An appropriate acoustical environment?

How to integrate active solar systems to the building.

info.learning_outcomes:
Buildings should be designed and erected to be comfortable and healthy. Since the available amounts of energy that can be used to ensure comfort is limited, constructive measures are preferred to technical ones (air conditioning, artificial lighting). Hence the architect has a major impact, by his design, on the indoor environment quality and on the fossil energy consumption of the building.

Course goals:

• Make the student aware of this reality.
• Review the comfort and health conditions, and teach constructive and technical means to fulfil them.
• Demonstrate ways for integrating active solar systems to the building.
• Present some building diagnosis methods.

info.exam_form_detail: Students prepare a written document and make an oral presenation
info.content:
The course will present the different approaches to industry analysis, as well as the different methodologies and tools which are generally used to perform such analyses. In this respect, Porter's five forces framework, the techniques used to analyse the degree of competition, the regulatory environment, the static and dynamic value chains, as well as other concepts and tools generally used to assess industry dynamics and trends will be presented.

Furthermore, the course will discuss future trends both from a theoretical as well as from a practical perspective. Finally, the course will also consider the issue of industry evolution and corresponding models, in particular the question of convergence across industries.

Starting for informational needs of a company, we will see how to identify and model information flows. We will then look at all the different existing types of packaged Information Systems, to point out their structure, functionnalities, as well as their strength and weaknesses.
With a starting focus on internally-managed informations, we will look at ERP, WMS and MES systems, Reporting and Business Intelligence applications, as well as Document Management and Workflow systems.

info.content:
The project is divided into a number of development steps that reflect different parts of the system to be constructed. The student implements one step after the other and gradually constructs a completely working system.

In the beginning of the project, techniques learnt in Introduction à la programmation objet are typically used to provide a practical implementation of a problem related to material learnt in Sciences de l'information, for example how to transfer a multimedia document over a channel that loses some information


Later in the project, the implementation is typically extended to a larger system using techniques learnt in the first part of Théorie et pratique de la programmation, for example by introducing a graphical interface, handling user mistakes through exceptions, etc.


Students work in pairs. At regular intervals during the project, they have a milestone meeting with a teacher and present the current state of their project. At the end of the project, there is an individual written test covering all aspects of the project.

Students experience independent development of a fairly large program. They get hands-on practice with modelling, programming and debugging. info.title: Internet : social challenges, global challenges I
info.exam_form_detail: Each student's research is to be confronted to the rest of the class during the first term of the year. The essay is to lead to an oral presentation during specific sessions at the end of the second term.
info.content:
Economy, politics, culture are all modulated by the double process of telecommunication intensification and simplification. They do so following both complex and often cryptic patterns. Within the process of creating both standardized and automatic flows and treatment of information, Internet so increases the individuals' capacities of exchange, of organisation, of production - in spite of the topographic distances that may separate them. Launched five decades ago, such a process has extended its magnitude during the last ten years, to the extent of disrupting the various elements structuring our "being together" - such as norms, ethics, practices and governance - underlining the fragility relative to the latter's only temporarily stable, and so often debated, legitimacy.

A full appreciation of the corresponding stakes requires an appropriate and renewed understanding of social facts at large (reorganisation of the various forms of intermediation, increased exposure of one's personal life, frailty of the digital identity, reconsideration of immaterial goods' market value). Seldom has it been so important to think simultaneously territories and networks, individuals and groups, humans and non-humans, technology and its applications, hardware and software, the tangible and virtual realities.

Students are to write an essay dealing thematically and illustrating effectively one of the following issues:
- Space: spatial action, spatiality (distance as an obstacle to social interaction)
- Internet: technology, norms, network, space, place (interspatiality, global and local scale)
- Individual being: privacy, trust, identity, the body (digital trail, avatar)
- Group: new intermediation process (hierarchy, collective intelligence)
- Society: ethics, norms and governance (copyright, conflict of interests).
info.learning_outcomes: To endow students with a critical thinking when facing the web, emphasizing the issues relative to world scale and the profusion of actors, as well as pointing out the correlated social stakes.

info.title: Introduction to Area and cultural studies (Part I)
info.content: The course will start with three sessions devoted to the theoretical framework of area and cultural studies, in order to provide the relevant tools deriving from cultural studies that will be used in the Minor. Three geographical areas will then be covered: East Asia, South Asia and the Middle East. The course will concentrate on contemporary processes and issues within single nations or sub-regions but it will also address, to some extent, cross-border exchanges and influences. Each session will explore a specific issue of particular relevance to the nation or the region considered. The classes will usually be divided into a two-hour lecture and a one-hour discussion, using also some reading material to be circulated in advance.
info.learning_outcomes: Social and political change, but also economic growth, improvements in productivity and the diffusion of technological innovations, can only be properly understood in their broader context, including social organization, economic relations and political culture. The aim of the first module of the EPFL Minor in Area and Cultural Studies is therefore to introduce the students to the societies and civilizations of Asia and the Middle East and to unravel some of the major issues affecting the social, cultural and political landscapes of these countries.

info.title: Introduction to Law and ethics in LS&T
info.content:
The course will be divided into five parts:

1. Introduction to ethics and law, distinction between law, ethics, professional rules, etc. (internormativity), the various sources of law and how they are adopted and implemented.
2. Legal notion of person, nature of the human body and body parts, nature and scope of the rights applying to them (personality rights, property rights, intellectual property rights, etc.), protection of the embryo (in vitro and in utero), protection of the cadaver.
3. Regulation of research involving human subjects and biobanks: basic notions, fundamental rules, conflicts of interests, protection of scientific integrity of research, legal requirements for collecting storing, processing, and transferring human biological material, data protection issues, biosafety, quality control, etc.
4. Legal status of the animal in constitutional and civil law, protection of the animals, ethical and legal requirements concerning research with the animals, ethical and legal framework concerning the GMO.
5. Basic elements of intellectual property, international and biotechnologies aspects.
info.learning_outcomes:
Provide an overview of the ethical debate in and the applicable law to the life sciences and technology.
At the end of this course, students will be able to identify the ethical and legal issues at stake in specific cases, find pertinent legal norms by using internet resources, and develop basic ethical and legal arguments. They should also be able to formulate a problem related to life sciences and technology in ethical and legal terms and identify situations where they should seek further legal assistance.

info.title: Introduction to astroparticle physics
info.content:
1. The observed universe: cosmological expansion, age of the universe, cosmic microwave background radiation.

2. Dark matter in the Universe. Rotation curves of the galaxies, experiments on detection of dark matter.

3. Astrophysical sources of high-energy gamma quanta and cosmic rays.

4. Pulsars and supernovae. Neutrinos from the supernova SN1987A.

5. High-energy particle acceleration near magnetized neutron stars.

6. Astrophysical black holes: stellar mass black holes and supermassive black holes in the nuclei of active galaxies.

7. High-energy particle acceleration and production of cosmic rays by the black holes.

8. Cosmic radiation: Spectrum, isotopic and spectral composition, means of detection, spallation mechanism, transport equations, propagation, standard leaky box model, cosmic clocks. AMS detector. First & Second order Fermi acceleration. Ultra high energy cosmic rays: detection. Atmospheric showers: profile, superposition principle, Bethe-Heitler model, composition. Interaction with the micro-wave background.

9. Electromagnetic radiation: Production mechanisms. Absorption mechanisms. On-board and ground-level detectors. CGRO & GLAST project. Cherenkov imaging. Sources of gamma rays with E>100 GeV. Origin of multi-wavelength spectra.

10. Neutrinos: Production mechanisms. Interaction with matter. Solar and atmospheric neutrinos, oscillations. Neutrinos from supernovae. Detectors and methodology. Transparent source model and Waxman-Bahcall flux. Flux model of AGN neutrinos.

info.learning_outcomes:
A manifold is a Hausdorff topological space locally homeomorphic to Rn. Under some general assumptions, one may consider differential manifolds to be a natural home for differential calculus and tensorial analysis.
Differential manifolds are the fundamental objects on which one builds differential geometry and topology, Lie groups, dynamical system, global analysis and many aspects of contemporary physics (analytical mechanics, general relativity, gauge theory, etc.).

The objective of this course is to learn the fundamental notions of the geometry of manifolds and to learn the basic calculus on them.
info.type_of_teaching: Ex cathedra lecture with exercises. This course follows the book of  L. W. Tu "An Introduction to Manifolds".

info.title: Introduction to multiprocessor architecture
info.content:
In this course, the students will learn about popular parallel programming interfaces, parallel program execution paradigms, parallel processor microarchitecture, multiprocessor memory systems, and on-chip and off-chip interconnects.

Like its uniprocessor counterparts (Introduction to Computer Architecture I & II), in this course we will have a term-long course project designing and implementing the logic neecessary to combine multiple processor pipelines with caches to form a simple but realistic cache-coherent shared-memory multiprocessor.
info.learning_outcomes: Multiprocessors are emerging as the architecture of choice to design chips for all segments of the computing market from smart phones, to set-top game boxes or workstations, to enterprise servers, to clusters, and finally to supercomputers. Most current and all future computers will indeed be multiprocessors. This course will build on the fundamentals of processor design and concurrent systems (both important pre-requisites) to cover the essential hardware technologies to combine multiple processing elements into a single computer.

info.content:
Overview : Specificities of the electromagnetic wave in the optical domain: intensity, corpuscular aspect, detection. Introduction to the different light theories and their approximation level : ray optics, wave optics, electromagnetic optics and quantum optics.

Electromagnetic optics : Application field of the vector model. Electromagnetic theory of light. Polarisation and Jones calculus. Reflection and refraction.

Guided-wave optics : Optical waveguides and fibres. Fabrication of planar optical circuits and optical fibres.

Light emission and detection : Field modes and photons. Emission and detection processes: interactions between photons and atoms. Photodetectors. Lasers
info.learning_outcomes:
Knowing the specificities of modern optics techniques, in particular the aspects related to the extremely high wave frequency and to light emission and detection based on the quantum nature of the field.
Acquiring basics for understanding, designing and achieving optical systems. Selecting the application areas where optics is more effective than systems operating in lower frequency ranges of the electromagnetic spectrum.

info.title: Introduction to planetary sciences
info.content:
INTRODUCTION
This course will contain an overview of planets, comets and asteroids that comprise the Solar System. We will also present materials and results obtained by robotic spacecraft and how this data changed our understanding of the Solar System. Students will have hands on exercise with the data. Latest publications in Science and Nature will be discussed.


HISTORY
Exploration of the Solar system began in 1957 with the launch of the first satellite. Since then, almost all planets have been imaged or visited by fly-by missions, orbiters or landers. Course will present the most important findings by the mission.


PLANETARY PROCESSES
Planetary science reviews all components of a planet: internal structure, surface processes and atmospheres. We will discuss internal structures of terrestrial planets and gaseous giants. Surface properties will include discussion of tectonics, volcanic eruptions and planetary ices. We will also discuss comets and asteroids. Students will benefit from an overview of many disciplines. Particular attention will be given to engineering aspects that are derived from our knowledge of the planets.


PRACTICE
Practical exercises will include review of papers, problem solving and data processing and analysis.
info.learning_outcomes: The goal of this course is introduce students into exciting world of planetary science. Students will learn about history of planetary exploration, how to use basic physics and mathematics to understand planetary processes and obtain some practical skills in data processing and analysis. In addition to basics, the course will explore latest result in this field. Particular attention will given on links between science and engineering.

info.title: Introduction to space science
info.content:
Introduction
Introductory material includes a short historical account, a discussion of rocket and planetary motion (Kepler's laws, rocket equation), and a review of space telescopes and space stations.
Solar System Formation
Formation and evolutionary processes have determined the properties of the Sun and planetary objects in the solar system. We will review protoplanetary disk formation and planetesimal accretion processes. We will take a brief tour of the solar system in its current state: planets, satellites, planetesimals (e.g. comets).
The Sun
The Sun affects all the processes in our solar system and is the ultimate source of energy for life on our planet. The solar interior, the magnetic field, the solar atmosphere, and the solar wind plasma will be discussed in detail. Transient events such coronal mass ejections and solar flares will be presented.
Space Plasma Physics
Interplanetary space is filled with a sparse plasma. Basic plasma phenomena will be discussed, e.g. plasma motion, boundaries, shock acceleration, and energetic particle populations.
Earth and Planetary Magnetospheres
Many planets possess an intrinsic magnetic dipole. The solar wind plasma interacts with this magnetic field, creating an intricate system of electromagnetic fields and currents, along with different local plasma populations. The terrestrial magnetosphere will be discussed in detail; other planets will be surveyed.
The Heliosphere and Beyond
The influence of the Sun ends where it interacts with the surrounding interstellar medium, defining the extent of the heliosphere. We will discuss the interaction of solar radiation, solar wind and magnetic field with the local interstellar medium, e.g. resulting in the termination shock and cosmic ray shielding.
info.learning_outcomes: In this course, we will introduce the student to the field of experimental space research. Spacecraft instruments have provided a wealth of knowledge about our solar system. This course provides the physics background and motivation for spacecraft instrument development as well as knowledge of the operational environment driving the spacecraft system design. We will cover the near-Earth space, the Sun, the planets and the heliosphere out to the limit of our solar system and beyond.

info.title: Introduction to the design of mechanical space hardware
info.content:
Introduction
A general overview of the space environment, the space vacuum and its residual gazes, radiations, thermal phenomenon, micro-gravity, vibrations will be presented. All have a very signifiant impact on the concepts and design of Space Mechanisms.

Essential design parameters
Elementary parameters such as mass, volume, cleanliness, temperature, etc. impose drastic constraints from the conception up to the final elaboration of a mechanism. The optimisation of these parameters is conditioned by the design, material properties and physical laws. The full extent of the engineer's imagination space is necessary to the success of a flight model.

Selected topics
As design aspects cover a very large field, we will, after a general introduction, present important chapters
related to space mechanisms in the form of selected themes, related in particular to:

• materials
• structure
• thermal aspects
• reliability

These themes will be presented with practical examples and certain details will be treated in exercise sessions.
info.learning_outcomes: The remarkable environment of the space mechanism, the very specific required functions to be met and the constraints of extreme reliability require from the engineer creative ideas often innovative compared to the solutions usual on earth. This lecture will prepare the student to meet this unexpected and fascinating world.

info.title: Introduction to turbomachinery
info.content:
I HYDRAULIC TURBOMACHINERY
1. Introduction to the hydraulic machine domain, main uses, driving or receiving machines.
2. Hydraulic characteristics of a piping system, discharge, specific energy of a cross section, energetic losses.
3. Motion in a rotating frame of reference: velocity polygon, 1st integral of the moment of momentum of the relative flow, application to the Pelton turbine runner.
4. Work received/done by a runner/impeller: Euler equation, hydraulic characteristics of a runner/impeller.
5. Elementary design of a runner/impeller of a Francis pump-turbine, a wind turbine or a propeller.
II THERMAL TURBOMACHINERY
1. Introduction: development, types and use of turbomachines, trends in development, economical aspects.
2. Principles of operation: equation of energy in the absolute and relative systems, work in the ideal and real turbomachine, efficiency, principles of gas turbine operation.
3. Elementary theory of axial and radial turbines: elementary calculation of turbines.
4. Elementary theory of axial and radial compressors: elementary calculation of compressors.
5. Characteristics of turbomachinery operation.
info.learning_outcomes: By using the modern fundamental engineering methods, to know how to properly design the primary components of a turbomachine while taking into account such important considerations as performance, durability, pollution and cost. In each chapter, the basic theories and principles are first explained, followed by discussions of practical applications as well as step-by-step descriptions of some typical examples.
