info.title: Selected Chapters in Medical Technology
info.content:
The course is organized in terms of weekly seminar series from clinical and medical technology experts which will expose to students important/critical clinical problems as adressed by medical technology (exluding parma and biotech). The structure of the course is based on alternating presentations in which a clinician exposes a particular clinical problem adressed by a given medical technology and in the following week an industry specialist analyzes current and future trends of the same medical technology.
Economical and regulatory aspects may also be included in the discussion.

Topics include (but not limited to):
- Endocascular prostheses (coronary and peripheral stents)
- Vascular grafts
- Orthopedic implants
- Pacemakers & defibrilators
- Artificial heart valves
- Dental implants
- Deep brain stimulation
info.learning_outcomes: Expose students to different aspects and current issues in medical technology

info.title: Selected topics in nuclear and particle physics
info.prior_knowledge:
Nuclear and particle physics I and II, Quantum mechanics I and II
Wished:Elementary particles physics I or Relativistic quantum fields I
info.content:
- Neutrino oscillations, MNS matrix.
- Absolute neutrino mass, beta and double beta desintegration experiments. Mass generation mechanism, Majorana and Dirac particles.
- Cosmic neutrinos : origin, energy spectrum and detection.
- Astronomic and cosmologic data on dark matter.
- Relic particles of the " Big bang". Candidates for dark matter, link with particle physics beyond the Standard Model.
- Direct and indirect searches of dark matter.
- Quark and gluon plasma. Implications in Astrophysics and Cosmology. Production in ion collisions. Plasma signatures.
info.learning_outcomes:
This course aims at introducing and studying several subjects in the field of particle and nuclear physics, some of which are linked to astro-physics. The following subjects will be discussed:
- Neutrino mass and oscillations.
- Motivation and implementation of experiments detecting cosmic neutrinos.
- Cosmologic evidence for " dark matter ", hypothesis concerning its nature and related research.
- Introduction of the concept of a new status of matter : quark and gluon plasma.
info.type_of_teaching: Ex cathedra and exercises in classrooms

title: Selected topics in nuclear and particle physics

info.title: Semiconductor components
info.content:
Electronic properties of Silicon
Band structure, carrier statistics. Transport properties, mobility, lifetime, diffusion length. Recombination. Continuity equations.
Junction diode and metal-semiconductor contacts
p-n junction under equilibrium and applied bias.
Current-voltage characteristics. Barrier potentials. Junction capacitance. Ohmic contacts.
Bipolar transistor
Intrinsic transistor model. Current-voltage characteristics. Large signal and small signal models.
Field effect transistors
JFET, MESFET structures. Principles and basic equations.
Metal-oxide-semiconductor structures
Interface band diagrams. Accumulation, depletion and inversion regimes. Capacitance-voltage characteristics. Charge-coupled devices.
MOS transistors
Current-voltage characteristics in strong inversion. Non-volatile memories. Linear and saturation regions.
Introduction to integrated circuits
Digital circuits: inverter, NOR, OR, switching time, dissipation. Analogue circuits: analogue switch, current source, differential amplifier. Comparison of semiconductor devices.
info.library_recomm:
• "CMOS : circuit design, layout, and simulation / R. Jacob Baker". Year:2008. ISBN:978-0-470-22941-5
  • "Composants à semiconducteurs : de la physique du solide aux transistors / Olivier Bonnaud". Year:2006. ISBN:978-2-7298-2804-2
  • "Semiconductor devices : physics and technology / S.M. Sze". Year:2002. ISBN:0-471-33372-7
info.learning_outcomes: The students will be able to understand the behaviour of the basic microelectronics components like Schottky and pn diodes, bipolar transistors, FET and MOSFET. They will be able to analyze their characteristics, to derive their simplified physical models and to discuss their basic electronic circuits like inverters and voltage amplifiers.

info.title: Semiconductor materials and properties, from the bulk to the nanostructure
info.content:
We will discuss the relation between the size and the fundamental properties of semiconductor materials. We will as well relate the added functionality related to the low dimensionality with the technological applications.
1. Introduction
2. Basic concepts of bulk semiconductors
3. Fabrication and synthesis techniques
- Top-down versus bottom-up
- Top-down fabrication techniques
- Bottom-up synthesis techniques from the vapor phase (MBE,CVD...)
4. Electronic transport properties of low dimensional semiconductors
5. Optical properties of low dimensional semiconductors
6. Applications
info.learning_outcomes:
In this course we will develop the concept of semiconductor materials with low dimensionality, as well as its role in today's and future electronic and optoelectronic applications.
We will relate the fundamental properties of bulk semiconductors with those of semiconductors whose dimensionality has been reduced.

title: Semiconductor materials and properties, from the bulk to the nanostructure

info.title: Sensors
info.content:
Metrological characteristics of transducers

Mechanical sensors: strain gages, piezoresistance. Applications: force, pressure.
Thermal sensors: resistance, thermocouples, semiconductor, thermopile. Applications: temperature, IR radiation, anamometry, mass flow.
Capacitive sensors: Capacitive readout interfaces. Applications: proximity, position, pressure, acceleration, microphone.
Inductive sensors: LVDT, variable reluctance, proximity.
Magnetic sensors: Hall, magnetostrictive, magnetoresistive.
Piezoelectric sensors: Materials, piezoelectric effect, readout interfaces. Applications examples: acceleration, microphone, pyroelectric sensors.
Resonant sensors: Principles, interfacing, quartz oscillators applications: force, pressure, temperature, micro-balances, gyroscopes, flow sensors.
Chemical sensors: Catalytic, conductance, electrochemical.
Optical sensors: General overview. Applications: encoder, integrated optics.

info.title: Set theory
info.content: Set Theory: ZFC. Extensionality and Comprehension. Relations, functions, and well-ordering. Ordinals. Class and transfinite recursion. Cardinals. Well-founded relations, Axiom of foundation, induction, and von Neumann's hierarchy. Relativization, absoluteness, reflection theorems. Gödel's constructible universe L. Axiom of Choice, and Continuum Hypothesis inside L. Po-sets, filters and generic extensions. Forcing. ZFC in generic extensions. Cohen Forcing. Independence of the Continuum Hypothesis. HOD and the Axiom of Choice: independence of the Axiom of Choice.
info.learning_outcomes: This course visits Set Theory as a foundation of mathematics. It introduces to I ndependence proofs, and relative consistency results, to show in the end that Hilbert's first problem is undecidable: does there exist an infinite set of reals that is neither in bijection with the set of integers, nor the set of reals (continuum hypothesis)?

info.title: Signal processing  for audio and acoustics
info.content:
Acoustics and audio is covered and the manipulation and processing of audio signals. It is shown how Fourier analysis of the soundfield yields to the representation of a soundfield with plane waves. These and other acoustic insights are used to explain microphone techniques and reproduction of the soundfield.
Spatial hearing is covered in detail and used to motivate stereo and surround mixing and audio playback.
The short-time Fourier transform is introduced as a tool for flexible manipulation of audio signals, suchs as filtering, delaying and other spectral modification. Matrix surround, audio coding, and beamforming are also treated.
info.prior_knowledge: Fourier transform, signal processing basics (sampling, filtering, discrete Fourier transform).
info.learning_outcomes: The objective of the course is to introduce theory, methods, and basic psychoacoustics needed to understand a wide range of techniques used in pro audio and consumer audio, including microphone techniques, surround sound, mixing, and audio coding.

title: Signal processing  for audio and acoustics

The tentative course contents are given below.

info.title: Signal processing for functional brain imaging
info.content:
• Brief overview of standard confirmatory processing (univariate methods)
• Stimulation paradigm (design and optimization, resting state)
• Functional connectivity (source separation methods such as principal components analysis and independent components analysis)
• Brain decoding (supervised machine learning)
• Multimodal imaging (simultaneous fMRI and EEG recordings)
• Sensory topographic mapping (high-field fMRI)
• Neurofeedback (real-time fMRI)
• Impact and significance for cognitive neurosciences and clinical applications
info.learning_outcomes: The aim of this course is to demonstrate how advanced signal processing techniques contribute to study brain function using modern medical imaging modalities. Over the past decade, seeing the brain at work has had a tremendous impact on neurosciences and medicine. The essentials of signal and image processing methods that lead to successful interpretation of functional brain imaging data are described, with a particular emphasis on multivariate techniques that jointly consider signals from various spatial positions. The proposed methodologies are widely applicable; particular examples include functional brain imaging using fMRI, EEG, and optical modalities.

title: Signal processing for functional brain imaging

4. Fourier transform

6. Application to communications
7. Analysis and synthesis of analog filters
8. Discrete signals and systems. Discrete convolution. z-transform

Application of these techniques to signal processing and communications. The first semester is devoted to the continuous-time formulation, while the second one focuses on discrete-time signals and digital systems.

This course teaches students how to develop software in the real world, work in large teams, be productive with code bases that cannot be comprehended in their entirety, and interact with real customers. Planning a feature, estimating total cost, packaging it up for distribution and maintenance are things that inexperienced developers rarely get right, but are vital for the success of a software project. Mediating between the needs of customers and the turn-coffee-into-code hacker attitude requires understanding both sides of the equation.



In this course (SDP), we pretend we are a start-up and continue to develop the EPFL Pocket Campus, a highly successful smartphone application that helps EPFL members locate their friends on campus, spot and rate the best lunch menus, manage courses, navigate on campus, etc. This coming semester we will substantially expand Pocket Campus with new components like augmented reality and Camipro cash payments.



An important prerequisite for SDP is the Software Engineering course: it must either be taken in parallel with SDP or have been taken in the past. The two courses are designed to be taken together.

SDP is a hard course and requires a significant time investment; the amount of work may exceed the number of credits, depending on the student's experience and ability to learn quickly and adjust to the realities of real-world software development. The rewards of this effort, however, are truly unique. Last year, after SDP was over, half the students taking it chose to continue working on Pocket Campus as part of their semester projects; this culminated in a public release of EPFL Pocket Campus on the Android app market.

info.title: Solid mechanics
info.content:
This course belongs to Mechanics as a basic science.
The general principles of mechanics, which govern the motion of deformable solid bodies, are extended from small perturbations to large transformations. These contents are divided into 4 chapters.
Chap. 1 is a prolongation of geometry and kinematics to large transformations (translations, rotations and strains).
Chap. 2 is an extension of statics and dynamics (forces, torques and stresses) at large transformations.
Chap. 3 is a survey of rational mechanics and energetics (real and virtual powers, energies) at large transformations.
Chap. 4 is a summary of isotropic elasticity : the linear law of isotropic elasticity, which is confined to small perturbations, is replaced by two non-linear objective laws, valid at large transformations, in order to close the problem.
The goal of the course is to formulate realistic models for analyzing the motion of flexible bodies or articulated systems of such bodies, such as some robots or the human body, constituted of compliant materials such as rubber or soft tissues.

info.title: Statistical signal processing and applications
info.prior_knowledge: Signal processing for communications; Mathematical signal processing : tools and applications
info.content:
1. Quick review to get started :
Signals and systems in the deterministic and stochastic case.
2. Methods and algorithms :
Parametric and non-parametric signal models (wide sense stationary, Gaussian, Markovian, auto regressive and white noise signals); Linear prediction and estimation (orthogonality principle and Wiener filter); Maximum likehood estimation and Bayesian a priori.
3. Statistical Signal Processing Tools for Ultra-Wide Band wireless transmission :
Coding and decoding of information using position of pulses (annihilating filter approach); Avoiding interference with GPS (spectral mask and periodogram estimation); Spectrum estimation for classical radio transmissions (estimating frequencies of a harmonic signal).
4. Statistical Signal Processing Tools for the Analysis of Neurobiological Signals :
Identification of spikes (correlation-based methods); Characterization of multiple state neurons (Markovian models and maximum likelihood estimation); Classifying firing rates of neuron (Mixture models and the EM algorithm).
5. Statistical Signal Processing Tools for Echo cancellation :
Adaptive filtering (least mean squares and recursive least squares)
info.learning_outcomes:
Statistical Signal Processing and Applications is the follow-up to Bachelor courses on signal processing, such as "Signal Processing for Communications", where the basics of signal processing were introduced.
Building up on the basic concepts of sampling, filtering and Fourier transforms, we addess spectral estimation, signal detection, classification, and adaptive filtering, with an application oriented approach : we first introduce relevant modern applications and the discuss appropriate statistical methods and tools to tackle them.

info.title: Statistical theories and electronic of solids
info.content:
1. Classical Maxell Boltzmann Statistics
Energy distribution law and partition function, basis of statistical thermodynamics and applications to derive the specific heat of solids (Debye Einstein), the value of equilibrium constants for chemical reactions as well as the entropy and the equation of state for an ideal gas.


2. Bose Einstein quantum statistics
Properties of Bosons, energy levels and distribution law for their occupancy, application to describe photons, the properties of black body radiation and to derive Planck's formula.

3. Fermi-Dirac quantum statistics
Properties of fermions, distribution law and occupancy of energy levels. Fermi energy and chemical potential of electrons.

4. Electronic theory of metals
Energy bands, density of state (DOS) as a function of energy, organic metals

5. Electronic theory of semiconductors
Energy bands, Brillouin zones, doping of semiconductors, organic semiconductors, p-n junctions, diodes and thin film transistors, photovoltaic cells.
info.learning_outcomes:
Acquire a solid understanding of the statistical theories of Maxwell Boltzmann, Bose-Einstein and Fermi Dirac.
See their applications in statitistical thermodynamics and understand the electronic properties of solids.

info.title: Statistics of extremes
info.content:
• Mathematical bases: behaviour of maxima and threshold exceedances in large samples, both for independent and dependent data.

• Statistical methods: modelling using the GEV and GP distributions, for independent and dependent data. Non-stationarity. Extremal coefficients. Multivariate data. Likelihood and Bayesian inference. Geostatistics of extremes.

• Applications: environmental, financial, and engineering applications. Use of R for extremal modelling.
info.learning_outcomes: The statistical modelling of rare events, such as stock market crashes, storms and catastrophic structural failures, is increasingly seen to be important. For example, the most destructive effects of climatic change are likely to be due to changes in extreme events, and events in the financial markets are also often modelled using methods from extreme-value statistics. This course will describe the special models and methods that are relevant to the analysis of such data, including the mathematical bases, statistical tools, and practical applications.

The objective is to use the analytical tools described throughout the course to diagnose a strategy.

Strategic management involves making decisions on the allocation of resources (tangible and intangible) to enable the business to generate profits in the long term. It applies to all levels of the organization and consists of the following branches :

- Corporate strategies relate to global strategy of the business;
- The business strategy applied by SMEs or the strategic business units (SBU) of a multinational;
- Functional strategies are applied to areas such as marketing, new product development, human resources, finance, legal, supply-chain and information technologies.

This course will be held as a seminar, in which the students actively participate. The talks will be assigned in the first meeting to teams of students, and each team will have to give a 45 minutes talk, react to other students' questions, and write a 3-4 pages summary of their talk.
info.learning_outcomes: This seminar introduces the participants to the current trends, problems, and methods in the area of communication security.

title: Student seminar : Security protocols and applications

info.title: Studio BA1
info.content:
A first group of investigations explore drafting space, visual perception, and geometrical syntax as an analytical process to engage imagination. This at first a-gravitational reality will then be confronted with our bodily existence. Consequently light will be introduced as a mediator between conceptual abstraction and physical existence.

A series of drawing-projects include an analysis of the functioning of the visual apparatus in living species, analytical methods of description of form and space: plan, section, axons, perspective and lead towards a first series of shop drawings for the fabrication of moulds for the respective projects.

The second half of the semester will be devoted to a first architectural project to be developed in a sequence of didactic steps. Fabrication of models and mock-ups will bring in the body and bodily perception and production into the process of developing architectonic thinking. This approach will be paralleled by the introduction of digital tools in the design process. 3d-software is implemented to understand drawing as 3d-space projected into the 2d-drafting-plane as analytical base for tectonic thinking: the process of drawing as a means to think space.
info.learning_outcomes:
Architecture projects into the future. It envisions environments, places of interaction, space. However, it never produces these spaces in an act of immediate creation. Rather it projects the envisioned into the future (time) and into space. The tools at hand of the architect, the strategic instruments, the projecting and surgical skills of intellect and imagination are at stake.

The first semester will focus on this field between actuality and the process of imagination. How can we explore our environment, synthesize sensorial perceptions and make sense of visual cues? How can we address gravitational and conceptual realities, relate space toward our body and thus scale the world against ourselves?

Such explorations must be based on a consciousness of our living environment as a source and resource of life. Our actions will have to be based on an understanding of ourselves as being part of cyclic flows and transitions, where both built and natural environments can be understood as mutual resources.

info.title: Studio BA2
info.content:
Building on the skills and the findings of the first semester the course will further investigate space and its development as living environment in highly dense conditions while at the same time integrating criteria aiming at the generation of high-identity environments: contrasting and integrating approaches towards organic and non-organic landscapes and built environments.

A modular system will form the basis for vertical grid configurations, which are to be developed by the students as spatial, programmatic and architectonic compounds.

The overall studio-project will conduct an experiment for possible visions of common spheres: our public and private living-domains.
info.learning_outcomes:
In 2008 for the first time more than 50% of humanity lived in cities. This value is predicted to approach 75% by 2050. This evolution in itself is not problematic since the city is widely regarded as the form of living with the greatest potential for sustainable coexistence.

In semester 2 we will therefore focus on the urban. How can we create environments, in which life-quality becomes a primary criterion for the creation and management of space? How can we densify cities and potentially redefine zones of structured nature? How can we create places of identity, find a balance between production and leisure, between activity and rest by using contrast and dynamic equilibrium as potentialities to store identity as latent energy: between the vertical and the horizontal, between the built and the unbuilt?

The program of semester 2 is designed to challenge our notions of the natural and the artificial to foster a planet-conscious approach for the design of our living environments.

info.title: Studio BA3 (Kuo)
info.content:
Throughout the year we will treat the studio as a laboratory for design speculation to provoke productive debates and critical positioning. The studio will be organized around a series of cumulative exercises and workshops. We will unpack historical as well as contemporary precedents while expanding on the tools and techniques of architectural thinking with individual projects. More specifically we will use large-scale models and prototyping, in parallel with digital tools, to understand the translation of concept to form. Photography and collage will be used to further exploit the physical modeling and to understand models as tools as well as artifacts.

Using the two semesters as complementary and dialectical halves of the year, we will focus on site and then on program as catalysts of concept, form, and organization to underscore their complicit effects in design. The first semester takes on multiple sites in deep nature to construct the architectural narrative of space and sequence while the second will focus on urban building typologies to question established interpretations of program and organization. The two semesters, raw nature and dense urbanity, will therefore also serve as a mirror to contemporary Swiss geography where the proximity of landscape and urbanism may redefine the role of architecture.
info.learning_outcomes:
Architecture is a speculative discipline. The creative act demands not only an understanding of the tools and techniques of design but above all a process of critique that sees problems and constraints as opportunities.

In this vein, the studio will take as its premise architecture as a construct. It is on the one hand a very literal material and technological construction: a system of parts to whole that negotiates between the figural object of the building and its organizational configurations. On the other hand, architecture is also the construction of a process, a methodology or a set of techniques that guides decision-making within the search for new relationships. We will address both of these ideas of construct. But above all, we are interested in a third kind of construct, and that is the conceptual construct - the fiction or the narrative - that we create in the positioning of our work, and without which design would simply be problem solving.

info.title: Studio BA3 (Rey)
info.content:
The activities of the studio are designed as a synergy between theoretical interdisciplinary contributions and specific trials of their integration into the architectural project. This twofold approach enables issues of conceptual, spatial and expressive cohesion to be dealt with, while at the same time exploring ways and means of turning the challenges of sustainability into a raw material for architects.

The particular aim is to study interactions between issues of density, mixed land use and quality of life, design buildings which take on board the principles of bioclimatic architecture and develop construction details in a manner which is consistent with fundamental notions of sustainability.

The project exercises are based on the search for creative solutions appropriate to the development of a dense and mixed urban site. They are worked out successively on the specific scale of the district, the building and its component parts.
info.learning_outcomes:
The trend towards spatial dispersion and functional dissociation of the built environment in recent decades is incompatible with the search for long-term equilibrium underpinned by the principles of sustainability. In fact, urban sprawl not only requires the use of large amounts of land but also generates important environmental impacts, accompanied by socio-cultural disparities and higher costs.

In this context, the architectural project is destined to play a central role in the search for alternatives, enabling urban development to be re-focused towards the town areas, the density of construction within easy access of public transport services increased and sustainable building techniques generated. By adopting an approach involving different scales of intervention - ranging from an urban project to the constructive details of buildings - the studio will seek to analyse, explore and experiment with the challenges inherent in this search for an architectural contribution to the sustainable city.

info.title: Studio BA5 (Bassi)
info.content: The urban areas to be investigated are part of the polycentric metropolis around Lake Geneva, beyond city, cantonal and country boundaries. Each semester a new site will be selected within this densifying area for an independent project assessment. Projects will have to integrate the mixed-use dimension and the transformation of the site's current status - mainly industrial areas - into an area dedicated to housing/offices/equipment. Simultaneously, our reflection will focus on the architectural outlook of façades as well as on structural aspects. Theoretical support will fuel project development in the form of in situ studies and conferences.
info.learning_outcomes:
The thrust of the reflections to be developed from 2011 to 2014 within the Laboratory of Urban Architecture (LAURE) will relate to architectural projects in sites outside urban and suburban areas. These "blossoming" sites are part of an "imaginary" metropolis whose growth is mapped through a series of hypotheses.

We have chosen an area undergoing profound changes, whose centre of gravity is defined by the empty space left by Lake Geneva. This "natural" void is circumscribed by a built environment whose varying degrees of density make up a polycentric metropolis able to host great functional diversity. We aim to draw up a picture of this metropolis through interventions in several of its urban centres.

The learning objectives aim at devising architectural projects in this context of ongoing urban or suburban development. We shall also reflect on the search for collective values (public areas, mixed-use, density) in urban areas. Students will learn to adopt a town planning and architectural attitude in the face of the metropolis development issue.

info.title: Studio BA5 (Graf F.)
info.content:
The protection project calls for a number of rational and technical investigations which will at once yield knowledge of the object of the study and define the uses of potential work to be carried out. The documentation of the building will be compiled with the help of historical research and graphic and photographic records, of its construction process and its material character, and of its sensitive and sensual aspects. The heritage value of the building will be determined by placing it in its historical, architectural and urban context, in the work of the actors that designed and built it, as well as in terms of its role as an economic and social resource. An analysis of its functional and distribution capacities, of its constitution and physical characteristics will dictate its potentials in terms of utilisation, maintenance and restructuring.

The protection project is a dual and inseparable project of conservation and renovation: the material substance of an existing building is conserved, preserved, reinforced, set off to advantage or returned to its original function, while at the same time something new is grafted onto this building to produce a prolongation of its life-cycle, a superimposition and juxtaposition of added elements. The project also concerns the reinforcement of a metal frame as well as the addition of a new functional body, and it focuses on the awareness of the relations and interfaces produced by their significance.

The workshop thus aims to familiarise students with the theoretical and practical elements of the development of the discipline of this project: of this "knowledge in action".

The object - and indeed the entirety - of this study and the subject of the project is linked to our daily heritage: that of the towns and countryside of post-war French-speaking Switzerland.
info.learning_outcomes: Today, work to be done on existing structures is a major stake in the development of the city of the 21st century and of the quality of the environment for its users. The protection project and the project to be pursued in existing structures are part of a composite cultural discipline that extends the borders of contemporary architecture. Building in built structures is not a new practice, far from it. What turns it into a contemporary attitude, however, is the kind of theoretical and practical questioning about the architectural object at all its scales, as well as a closer look at the material character of the building, which both give rise to the project.

info.title: Studio MA1 (Berger)
info.content:
Project as tool of analysis and understanding

Workshop exercises and research focus on subjects treating urban and territory scale. Special attention is paid on the simultaneous morphogenesis of the natural environment and the built-up areas. Their apparent and induced geometry are carefully observed with an aim of better understanding processes of cross influences having led to their current complexity.
The architectural form results from the conjunction of an urban vision and a program that answer the question raised by a context and a request. Today, these two optics tends to exclude each other. City planning is emptied of its architectural substance, whereas programming is reduced to a simple response to the needs. The workshop interest point is to acquire the know-how about the master plan idea. The conceptual process thus leads the creative imaginary around the program, which generates the urban form.

End of the text, see Studio MA 2.
info.learning_outcomes:
It is generally acknowledged that our environment, cultures and lifestyle are urban. Though this phenomenon has been clearly identified as the result of the evolution of uses and social functions. The perceptible shape of the urban environment has reached a level of complexity that makes it difficult to understand or to simply represent.
The available tools - typological, morphological or historical - to analyse our current reality, are no longer sufficient to grasp the complexity of a given context. In a similar way, the traditional meaning assigned to words such as city, town, village, rural, urban, or even suburban, have lost their power to circumscribe this reality.
The questions addressed by today's urbanism are the understanding of a new form of urban environment, its representation, as well as the definition or development of new strategies to act upon it.
Three research orientations has been elaborated in order to address these questions by UTA laboratory:
• Understanding and representing the natural and built environment
• Programmes and their effects on cities morphogenesis
• Project as main tool at the scale of the environment and of the city.

info.title: Studio MA1 (Gugger)
info.content:
At lapa we offer a year long course. The first semester we work on an urban scale. The investigation is structured in 4 assignments and results in what we call an "Urban Constitution" (UC). The UC consists of a Constitution text and a Zoning Plan.

During the second semester we work on the scale of an architectural project. Based on the UC the students define their own site and program for an architectural project which they then have to develop in 4 design phases. These projects act as "Proof of Concept" testing the viability of the UC.

You find more detailed information on our teaching method by visiting our website > lapa.epfl.ch > teaching > lapa_Methodology.pdf.
The specific location for our investigation of the coming academic year will also be announced on our website.
info.learning_outcomes:
The name of the laboratory indicates that this is a place where architecture is produced, a place devoted to the study and research of creating architecture. Using the term "production" underscores our view of architecture as an intellectual, crafted, machine-made and artistic product.

When we speak of architecture we mean the entire lifecycle of a project: from development, planning and construction to the use of the building. This all-inclusive aspect is also rendered by the term "production" since it designates both the creation of an intellectual commodity and the making of manufactured goods.
It is the primary task of the laboratory to ensure the architect's continued participation in the planning and building process as a central, integrating and coordinating force. The laboratory teaches the architects to become leaders in the creation of the built environment.

info.title: Studio MA1 (Huang)
info.content:
We examine such questions at the intersection of physical and digital architecture through:

• introduction to algorithmic processes in architecture;
• digital fabrication of non-repetitive 3D geometries;
• experimentation with expressive prototypes;
• site-specific project work.
info.learning_outcomes:
The studio "Interactive City - Organicités" examines the effects of digitalization on the making of architecture in the contemporary city.

• How do conceptions of space and tectonics change with the infiltration of new elements of interactivity?
• How will digital form-making and fabrication change architectural production?
• What are the new functional and aesthetic potentials that become available to us?
• What can architects learn from the study of complex natural phenomena? How can this study inform the design of analogously rich and adaptive architectural forms?
• And, what role should algorithmic processes play in the invention of form? How does material thickness affect the digital design process?

info.title: Studio MA1 (Lamunière)
info.content:
We will use architectural design as a means of investigating the relationship between nature and the urban in the contemporary city.

The initial project phase will focus on analysis (observation, notation), in a contemporary metropolitan environment, of the intimate and necessary relationship that exists between the city and nature in order to arrive at a definition of this relationship. The second phase of project work will involve constructing effects that capture the intrinsic energy of nature's presence within dense urban environments; communicating by rational means the poetic forms generated by the observation of nature in the city as a source of pleasure, meaning and emotion; focusing on the theme of environmental space rather than immediate environment and on the idea of climate as a local rather than generic phenomenon.
info.library_recomm:
• "Fo(u)r cities : Milan, Paris, Londres, New York / Inès Lamunière". Year:2004. ISBN:2-88074-520-9
  • "Habiter la menace / Inès Lamunière ; avec des contrib. de Peter Brun ... [et al.] ; et des photogr. de Leo Fabrizio". Year:2006. ISBN:978-2-880746-50-6
  • "Natural and urban, green and grey : studies on specificities of contemporary urban architecture / Inès Lamunière, Roberto de Oliveira Castro, Jean-Paul Jaccaud". Year:2008
info.learning_outcomes:
The meteoric growth of the last twenty years has fundamentally modified our concept of the city. The regional sprawl of urbanised areas has brought major changes to their inhabitants' lifestyles and mobility. Faced with such rapid and radical transformations it is increasingly difficult to pin down a definition of urbanity that is both cohesive and contemporary. The city is everywhere, the city is nowhere; concepts of centrality, of historic identity, of suburbs and periphery, of countryside, of nature and of density merge and dissolve in a complex reality whose exact properties remain unclear.

The primary academic mission of the "Laboratoire d'Architecture et de Mobilité Urbaine" (Laboratory of Architecture and Urban Mobility) is to investigate this elusive contemporary city. Guided by architectural, environmental, political, social and economical concerns we will focus our scrutiny, in particular, on the complex relations that exist between the natural and the urban, between Green and Grey.

info.title: Studio MA1 (Ortelli)
info.content: The Siedlungen of Berlin and Frankfurt, modern classicist housing in Stockholm and Copenhagen, as well as the Wienerhöfe, are all case studies. This project, which will be located in one of those cities each semester, will provide an opportunity to become familiar with their structures and characters. The project will also constitute an instrument for the verification of the hypothesis whereby social housing is able to contribute towards the definition of an urban identity and assume a "collective" character. This latter idea is the object of a continued examination of a viewpoint that is both programmatic and strictly architectural. This project will attempt to answer the crucial question as to how to arrive at an architectural definition of the collective nature of a habitat and of the public spaces through which it is organised.

info.learning_outcomes: This workshop has a twofold purpose: on the one hand, the development of a social housing project that is conceived as an urban construction project, and on the other hand, a critical consideration of the implications that such a project gives rise to. The point is to expand on and advance the discourses which modern architecture has developed in this field and to explore the way in which these theories have produced a genuine impact on the city. Inside the constellation of the Modern Movement, a number of experiments have given a precise connotation to the cities in which they have been realised, thus contributing to the definition of the character of those cities. Continued theoretical commitment will be required as it is an indispensable instrument for both the construction of the project and the definition of a general point of view regarding the housing issue.

info.title: Studio MA1 (Weinand)
info.content: Conception of a spatial structure: teamwork of architects and civil engineers.
info.learning_outcomes:
The studio's objective is the integration of structural constraints in the architectural conception. Architectural and structural notions are intimately linked.

Civil engineers will take part at the form finding process and they will participate defining the project's geometry. The integration of engineers intends to stimulate inventive processes (complementary to the creative ones) in order to develop a form or geometry by applying to this form the engineers critical views. The dialogue with the engineers will help the architects to improve form and construction considerations simultaneously. The privileged support of that communication will be the model as a crystallisation point helping to define the general form and the constructive principle and details during the inventive process.

Studio's participants will have the opportunity to follow a series of lectures concerning major structures realized by modern masters such as Nervi, Dieste, etc.

info.title: Study and analysis of energy systems
info.content:
A Basic physical and thermodynamical phenomena
Forces : Newton law, limits of Newton mechanics, elementary forces and fields of forces.
Definition of energy.
Energy conservation.
Entropy : Quality of energy, exergy, units.

B Energy and socio-economy
Energy and sustainable development; energy and society.
Historical evolution of the energy consumption.
The evolution of energy demand.

C Energy vectors, reserves and resources
Fossil fuel : coal, oil, natural gas.
Composition, characterization and uses, resources, reserves, extraction, prospecting, processing, transportation, price.
Nuclear fuels
Renewable energies : hydro, solar, wind and geothermal energy.

D Power generation
Fossil fueled power plants, nuclear power plants, hydroelectric power, solar power plants, wind and geothermal energy power plants.

E Impact of energy generation and distribution
Methods of analysis : technological, environmental and economic criteria, safety and risks.
info.learning_outcomes: At the end of the course, the student will have assimilated some fundamental knowledge in energy and will be able to have his own judgement on energy uses. He will also have a good understanding of the role of energy in a sustainable socio-economic development.

info.title: Supersonic and hypersonic flows
info.content:
• One dimensional unsteady flows : Isentropic flow, simple waves, compression and expansion waves, shock formation, piston, shock tube,
• Riemann invariants, introduction to the Riemann problem, initial and boundary conditions.
• High-resolution shock-capturing methods : Upwind and centered schemes for linear hyperbolic PDE's. Conservative schemes. Monotonic schemes. Numerical flux. Godunov method. Riemann solvers. Entropy condition. Limiters. TVD schemes. Boundary conditions. Supersonic and hypersonic flows, as well as combustion.
• Assessment of computational results.
info.prior_knowledge:
• ME-343, Compressible flows, or equivalent
• ME-371, Finite difference and finite volume methods, or equivalent
info.learning_outcomes:
Domain Skills:
• AH1, Describe flow in scientific terms
• AH2, Link flow behaviour with non-dimensional parameters
• AH3, Describe physical phenomena associated with compressibility
• AH10, Identify the crucial aspects present in a real flow in order to propose an appropriate modelling
• AH16, State the conserved quantities in a given flow and link them to a physical-mathematical description
• AH21, Apply the methods of characteristics to the analysis of supersonic flows
• A24, Choose the numerical approach appropriate for the accurate computation of shock locations in a compressible flow
• AH28, Evaluate numerical accuracy as a function of the choice of simulation parameters
• AH29, Analyse numerical solutions and identify any inconsistencies with respect to physical reality; understand and apply the concepts of verification and validation
• AH30, Describe different method used to discretize differential equations
• AH41, Perform a numerical simulation with appropriate software
Transverse skills:
• T2, Self-assessment of acquired skills
• T7, Make an oral presentation
• T23, Improve skills continuously

info.title: Supply chain management
info.exam_form_detail: Continuous evaluation of the experimental part; final exam in groups of the theoretical part; report and presentation of the case studies during the semester.
info.content: Dilemma of local versus global optimization of a value adding network, information sharing, customer/supplier relationships, degrees of collaborative operations management (Beer Game on a multi computer simulation platform). Mathematical modeling of supply chain dynamics. Explicit analysis of order-based, inventory-based strategies with forecasting and commitment windows. More information: http://lmom.epfl.ch/teaching
info.learning_outcomes: This course aims to demonstrate that the properties of advanced polymer materials depends on both their molecular structure, i.e., constitution and configuration, and their interamolceular as well as intermolecular non-convalent interactions. The former control the conformation of a polymer chain (i.e., its overall shape and shape persistence), while the latter determine the aggregation and microphase segregation of polymers. Consequently, these non-covalent interactions give rise to hierarchical structure formation and exert an important influence on the material properties. In analogy to modern organic chemistry and biochemistry, the preparation of advanced polymers tries to take these aspects into account. The building blocks used in modern polymer synthesis often attempt to encode the supramolecular behavior into the molecular structure. The course aims to provide an understanding of the underlying principles, discuss the consequences and give illustrative examples of modern applications, such as organic optoelectronic materials, shape-memory polymers, or self-assembled nanoscopic objects.

info.title: Technology strategy & corporate entrepreneurship
info.exam_form_detail: Group projects, class participation, exam/quizzes, paper critique
info.content:
The competitiveness of large, established corporations is continuously being challenged in today's fast changing environment. In an effort to find ways to stay competitive, executives in these organizations are recognizing the critical role that entrepreneurial thinking plays in creating opportunities for growth and renewal. This course will focus on how entrepreneurial skills and processes can be applied effectively in corporations. It will examine the theory and best practices associated with the process of converting new ideas to new products, technologies and businesses, within the boundaries of a large corporation.

The course will focus on topics such as designing and encouraging organizational contexts that promote innovation and creativity, corporate investments in new ventures and their uses to the investor, briefly survey alliances, joint ventures and acquisitions and key success factors for achieving success, how organizations exploit assets (such as intellectual property and complementary assets) for innovation and growth. During the course, the participants will be placed in the role of a project manager or key decision maker and asked to address issues related to the creation and reinforcement of both an individual business venture and an innovative parent organization.
info.learning_outcomes: The central focus of the course is to examine how large corporations can become more adept at creating opportunities for change, capitalizing on them, and reacting to disruptive changes in the environment. Accordingly, the course objectives are two fold: (1) to develop an awareness and understanding of the range, scope, and complexity of issues involved in the creation of an organizational climate that helps recognize, nurture, and grow entrepreneurial activities within large firms; (2) to gain insight into the effective commercial exploitation of technological and organizational innovations in such a context.

info.content:
This course covers the analysis and implementation of test techniques for digital VLSI. Regular class lectures form the core of the course.

Introduction to test theory
Introductory topics cover the role of testing, automatic test equipment and an overview of the economics of test.

Test methods
In a second part, fault modeling and test methods are studied. The major topics that will be considered are related to fault simulation, automatic test-pattern generation (significant combinational and sequential ATPG algorithms), measures of testability and miscellaneous test methods. Industry popular models and algorithms are presented and exercised.

Design for testability
A third part sets the focus on design for test (DFT) techniques. Tackled topics include scan design, built-in-self-testing (BIST - LFSR and signatures) and the Boundary-Scan standard (JTAG). Testing of memory circuits is also presented.
Aside from theoretical lectures, a number of course modules are devoted to in-class guided exercise sessions, and hand-on computer laboratory sessions, which take place along the semester and complement with a practical-oriented presentation of the topics.

The goal of this course is to provide a solid and mathematically precise understanding of the fundamental capabilities and limitations of computers and software, as well as their relevance to computer and software engineering practice.

info.title: Theories of urban design I
info.content: Theory of Urbanism I and II deals with models, projects, techniques and instruments of urbanism from 18th century to present. Content will be organised following both historical development and thematic structure (Utopia, typologies of urban spaces, variety-repetition-regularity, isotropy, urban centre-urban district-neighbourhood unit, bird's eye view-on foot approach). According to a wide consideration of urban project and of its elements (both natural and build ones), gardens and parks will be dealt with as a field of innovation and experience for urbanism.
info.learning_outcomes: The wide field of city planning has been generated from the confluence of various disciplines and savoir-faire, in order to establish the best conditions for transitivity between social imagination and reality. Theory of Urbanism I and II focus on the contribution of architecture and design culture to city planning. Bachelor Students are given a fundamental knowledge on Theory of urbanism (as they are on the fields of history and theory of architecture, representation and building technology), which will allow them to chose Master elective classes and to take up further interdisciplinary challenges.

info.title: Theory of architecture I
info.content:
Four "tales" regarding the origin of architecture

1. Framing
2. Cladding
3. Foyer
4. Measure.

5. Vernacular construction and longevity
6. Smart construction and innovation
7. Regularity (and classicism)
8. Irregularity (and picturesque).

9. The closed order (the room)
10. The open order (the open plan)
11. Contemporary architecture 1
12. Contemporary architecture 2.
info.learning_outcomes: The course is an introduction to the principal notions and concepts behind the theory of architecture.

info.title: Theory of architecture II
info.content: See Theory of architecture I.
info.learning_outcomes: See Theory of architecture I.

info.title: Theory of architecture III
info.content:
• Changes in the Eigteenth Century: Architecture, history and territory.

• Combination and assemblage. J.-N.-L. Durand and the "Marche à suivre dans la composition d'un projet quelconque".

• The Beaux-Arts composition. Composition and suite of symmetrical rooms.

• Elements of architecture / Elements of composition. J. Guadet and the problem of the room.

• Architecture and expression of the construction 1. E. Viollet-le-Duc, A. Choisy and constructive rationalism.

• Architecture and expression of the construction 2. A. Perret and structural classicism.

• Contrast and balance 1. The agglutinative plan.

• Contrast and balance 2. From the "pittoresque grec" to the "plan libre".

• Composition and generation. F.L. Wright and architectural grammar.

• Composition and abstraction 1. H. P. Berlage and the Amsterdam School versus De Stijl and Neoplasticism.

• Composition and abstraction 2. De Stijl and Neoplasticism.
info.learning_outcomes:
The cycle of the composition

Lectures are based on treatises and texts on architectural theories, and on the analysis of remarkable buildings and projects. Lectures aim to give an appreciation of the problems relating to architectural composition from the beginning of the Nineteenth Century to the Avant-Garde of the Twentieth Century.

info.title: Theory of architecture IV
info.content:
• The destruction of the box. Frank Lloyd Wright, the Prairie houses and organic architecture.

• Peter Behrens and the monumentalization of the industrial architecture.

• The Raumplan. Adolf Loos and the principals of architectural tradition.

• Walter Gropius and the centrifugal form of the Bauhaus building.

• Ludwig Mies van der Rohe, the free plan, open spaces and enclosed courts.

• The free plan. Le Corbusier and Les cinq points de l'architecture nouvelle.

• The rational plan and the aesthetics of taylorism.

• The flexible plan, the Domino and Citrohan units. The Weissenhofsiedlung at Stuttgart (1927).

• The primacy of dynamics. The architectural experiences of the Russian avant-garde.

• Alvar Aalto and the humanist approach of functionalism.

• Giuseppe Terragni and the Italian rationalist architecture.
info.learning_outcomes:
This course deals with the 1920's and 1930's architectural "avant-gardes" and explains their theoretical and doctrinal domaines.

The course will be based on major examples of architecture and will also refer to other not so wellknown examples, which allow us to have a better understanding of the diversity of this period of the 20th century.

info.title: Theory of architecture V
info.content:
The disenchantment due to World War II has defeat the idealistic trend and the faith into technical means of Modern Movement architects. Instead, a new interest in reality as it is rose up. This course explores the different manifestations of this new standpoint, and tries to understand the strong influence it got on the way to conceive architecture, its status and its meaning.

• Ordinary reality vs. banal reality: definitions/distinction. Auguste Perret, Alison and Peter Smithson, Robert Venturi.
• Mass housing: from french grands ensembles to british new towns.
• Another look at mechanization: countryside modern organization, from Radiant Farm to rural reallotment.
• The rise of Team 10 : Athens Charter vs. Urban Reidentification. From Radiant City to megastructure.
• Assemblages: connective architecture, clusters, neighbourhood units.
• As found: architecture without rhetoric, Le Corbusier, Alison et Peter Smithson, New Brutalism, Free cinema.
• New Monumentality: question of representation. Rediscovery of the traditional city and its qualities, The Heart Of The City, frome the last projects of old modern masters (Neue Nationalgalerie, couvent de la Tourette, palais Finlandia, etc.) to the koolhaassian auto monument.
• Context, history and realism: Post war Italy, Hansaviertel vs. Stalinallee, Colin Rowe, O.M. Ungers, Diener & Diener.
• Learning from vernacular architecture : the search for the genuineness of a direct esthetic : Karl Friedrich Schinkel, Adolf Loos, Le Corbusier, James Stirling, Bernard Rudofsky, Aldo Van Eyck, Lacaton Vassal.
• Louis Kahn: still modern, already post-modern.
• Aldo Rossi: from Analog city to Analog architecture.
• Robert Venturi : from Rome to Las Vegas.
info.learning_outcomes: To provide theoretical and historical references in the recent period, to help students to better understand the conceptual substratum in which are rooted contemporary architecture issues.

info.title: Theory of architecture VI
info.content:
Composition and noncomposition

During the sixties, new approaches of the architectural project cast doubt on conceptions of modern architecture, which are now traditional. New themes are developed which open new perspectives for the architectural work. The lectures will try to understand the problematics and themes, which have just up to now marked the present time.

• The Brutalism. Alison & Peter Smithson and the European scene.

• The megastructures. Web and Stem.

• Assemblage versus composition. Le Corbusier.

• Served spaces, servant areas: the question of poché. Louis I. Kahn.

• Void versus space: the American metropolis. Towards a new environment.

• New environment and architecture 1.
Robert Venturi & Denise Scott Brown: duck and decorated shed.

• New environment and architecture 2.
Aldo Rossi: analogous city and historicism.

• New environment and architecture 3.
Oswald Mathias Ungers et Colin Rowe: the archipelago city.

• New environment and architecture 4.
Rem Koolhaas: the generic city.

• Non compositional process 1. Logics of plans and neutral plan.

• Non compositional process 2. Logics of operations.

• Non compositional process 3. The question of the environment.
info.learning_outcomes: Knowledge of the architectural theories and doctrines after the second world war.

info.title: Theory of architecture VII
info.content:
Architecture and art

• Cubism (Braque, Picasso), transparency and space (Walter Gropius, Le Corbusier).
• Art brut (Paolozzi, Dubuffet), brutalism, "other" architecture and the truth about materials (Le Corbusier, Smithson).
• Ready-made (Duchamp) and new materials (Lacaton and Vasal, OMA); pop art (Richard Hamilton, Jasper Johns, Andy Warhol) and symbolic work (Robert Venturi).
• Minimal art (Donald Judd, Robert Morris, Carl Andre) and simplicity.
• Land art (Robert Smithson, Michael Heizer, Walter de Maria) and scale.
• Art Concret (Max Bill, Erwin Herrich) and rule.
• Richard Serra and place.
info.learning_outcomes:
Among the questions raised today by contemporary architecture, we can cite the relationship, at the same time problematic and simulative, that it attempts to weave with art.

The goal of the course is to clarify the complex nature of these relationships as they appear in contemporary architecture: on the one hand to place it in a diachronic and historical perspective, notably starting from the modernity of the 20th century; on the other hand by using a critical reading of the writings and work of the architects who are registered, in a more or less declared way, in the mobility of these artistic currents.

info.title: Theory of architecture VIII
info.content:
Adventurous coherences - Changes of paradigms
The conception of an architectural project is guided by principles.
These principles may be implicit: they belong to the "spirit of the time", to the habitus.

Theses principles may be explicit: they are objects of the exposition of a theory.

Implicit or explicit, the principles are neither immutable nor universal. They are situated in a context of understanding the world, in the perspective of its transformation.

The principles of architectural conception are necessarily precarious. They correspond to points of view: the coherences are always adventurous.

Lectures take an interest in the contemporary period. The hypothesis is that the changes of paradigms result from three parameters:

• The worldwide economy: does it mean the deletion of all "regionalist" understanding of architecture?
• The growth of the metropolis: does it mean new contextual conditions for the architectural project?
• The advent of new abilities of representation: does it mean that they are new abilities of conception?
info.learning_outcomes: The purpose of the lectures is to identify and understand the changes of paradigms in architectural theories and the contemporary period: how new wordings become predominant and what are the consequences of their emergence or advent?

info.title: Theory of materials : from structure to properties II
info.prior_knowledge: basic knowledge of classical mechanics and electromagnetism
info.content:
1. Introduction to quantum mechanics.
Wave and particle duality. Schroedinger equation. Heisenberg uncertainty principle. Hydrogen atom.
2. Atomic bonds and crystals
Ionic bond. Van der Waals bond. The diatomic molecules: covalent bond. Hybridation of atomic orbitals: a few organic molecules. Metallic bond.
3. Model of electrical and thermal conductivity
Chain of classical and quantum oscillators. Bose-Einstein and Debye. models. Specific heat. Thermal conductivity.
Model of free electrons. Thermal conductivity of electrons. Electrons in a periodic potential: band theory. Semiconductors and electronic devices.
4.Magnetism
Magnetic moments: paramagnetism et diamagnetism. Introduction of spin. Exchange interaction. Ferromagnetism.
5. Electron-phonon coupling: superconductivity
Superconductivity phenomenology. High critical temperature superconductivity.
6. Dislocation dynamics
Elastic theory of dislocations. Interactions with structure defects. Anelasticity and mechanical spectroscopy.

• "Introduction to dislocations / Derek Hull and D.J. Bacon". Year:2011. ISBN:978-0-08-096672-4

info.learning_outcomes: This course describes the physical laws needed to understand some properties of solids. However, these properties cannot be deduced directly from the chemical end physical properties of the elements. It is necessary to establish a theory of particle interactions and or their collective movements. A brief introduction to quantum mechanics is the basis to treat phonons and thermal properties, the band theory and electrical conductivity, spin and magnetism. The final part of this course describes the dynamics of defects in solids and particularly the theory of dislocations.

Study of different transient behaviours under network supply : switching-on, switching-off, starting-up, short-circuits, effect of saturation.

Frequency converters supply.
info.learning_outcomes: At the end of this course, the student will be able to use different methods in order to choose and model the most important types of medium-sized and large electrical machines. He will be able to foresee the behaviour and the constraints in steady-state and transient conditions by taking into account interactions between electrical machines and other elements of power networks or speed drive systems.

info.title: Tribology
info.content:
BASIC PRINCIPLES
Elastic/plastic contacts, friction, lubrication, deformation and fracture in contacts, wear, third body and tribological flow, experimental techniques.

MATERIALS AND CONTACTS
Metals and alloys, ceramics, coatings, polymers and composites.

SURFACE CHEMISTRY AND TRIBOLOGY
Reaction layers, tribocorrosion, boundary lubricated wear.

APPLICATIONS
Bearings, biomedical implants, micro-technology, materials forming.
info.prior_knowledge: Introduction à la science des matériaux
info.learning_outcomes:
Tribology is the science of contacting surfaces in relative motion. It includes technical relevant phenomena such as friction, wear and lubrication.

Such phenomena play an essential role for energy and material conservation, a relevant aspect for sustainable development.

This course is an introduction to tribology with specific goals :
- To present the basic principles of tribology and of the system approach.
- To develop the attitude to analyse tribological systems and to identify material requirements.
- To familiarize the student to the correlation between materials properties and tribological behaviour.
info.type_of_teaching:
Ex cathedra with exercises and case studies
2 presentations by external speakers (in French)

info.title: UE B : Architectural critique
info.content: Through the analysis of buildings of collective housing, it deals with specifying a few questions such as: building typology and ways of life, density and its effects on the conception of domestic spaces, atmospheres and sensitive perceptions.

Questions related to contemporary housing

info.title: UE C: Architecture and Archeology
info.content:
• Presentation of the general issues regarding the relationship between architecture and archeology.
• Explanation and discussion of exemplary projects realized in an archaeological context.
• Presentation of the site of Eretria and study of the framework of the project.
• Realization of the project of the archaeological park of Eretria.
info.learning_outcomes: The teaching unit aims to stimulate and promote the interest in the issues regarding the relationships between architecture and archaeology, and it strengthens the ability to realize a suitable architectural intervention in an archaeological context. The work subjects are provided by the Department of Archaeology at the University of Lausanne (Prof. Karl Reber) as a part of a collaboration with the EPFL on the archaeological excavations in progress. Basing both on the theory and on a series of examples, the teaching unit will provide the instruments to define the guidelines for an architectural project in an archaeological site. The goal is to explore the objectives and the modalities of the implementation of an archaeological park in the ancient city of Eretria. The main objects of the reflections are the construction of a route in the area of the house of the mosaics, as well as a study of a larger pedagogic route, which includes all excavations currently present in the archaeological perimeter. Several types of interventions (museographic, in the restoration, in the protection of the excavations) may also be included in the overall project.

info.title: UE D : Territory and society
info.content:
To study this problematic we will examine more specifically one user category of the city of Lausanne: Children , their places, their interactions, their moving around.

The UE will be devoted, to the study of public spaces of the city centre and to understand to what extent considerations on children has had a part in planning such spaces. Study work will be devoted to observation and enquiries on the existing practices of children (and care taking adults) and on the reflections that have been devoted to children as users of the city centre. Students will be asked to develop a research problematic and to provide answers to it through field work.
info.learning_outcomes:
The UE "Territory and Society" aims to familiarize architects with comprehensive human sciences methods and to give them prospective tools to analyse the impacts of formal change on activities, frequenting and image of places.

UE D will in particular develop thinking on the user of the built environment and conveys students to explore ways of integrating such thinking into a project.

info.title: UE E : Architecture and structures
info.content:
Exercice option: the chosen theme for the current academic year is a lightweight construction upon an existing construction.

The exercise will study the following aspects:

• Concept formalization, structural and architectural expression, honesty in construction,

• Structure and materialization (from function to superstructure, static diagrams, stability, load bearing, ground details, supports),

• Architectural language and construction premises (plan, section, elevation), integration/ dissociation between elements, equivalence of means towards construction and the relevant expression,

• Hierarchy (conception, scale, perception, construction).

Research option: possibility to do research work on the theme of lightweight construction with a program to be determined.
info.learning_outcomes:
• To propose an investigation into space and form by integrating questions of structures: spatial perception and architectural expression.

• To acquire the means to develop a structure together with an architectural concept and brief: variation studies in order to find the correct form.

• To confront spatial and structural conception along with other parameters of the architectural project:
- materials and their characteristics;
- comfort as in: natural light, acoustic quality, thermal quality (reference to these notions throughout the design process).

info.title: UE F : Architecture and rehabilitation
info.content:
Case studies including real buildings to which will be applied in the first phase an analytical and appraise approach followed by a diagnosis and a global intervention concept.

In a second phase, the intervention measures via an interdisciplinary approach is to incite the study of and the presentation of propositions in relation to the materialisation of the architectural intentions. Within this frame work the student will proceed with the verification of the chosen solutions aided notably by efficient computer programmes.
info.learning_outcomes:
• To know the theoretical and practical basis of the analysis in the field of refurbishment with applied case studies.

• Study and apply rapid diagnosis-evaluation methods developed for this purpose.

• Formulate a clear synthesis concerning buildings.

• Define an intervention concept and communicate it in an efficient and convincing manner.

• Progressively develop a refurbishment project in collaboration with different parties and achieve advanced studies for various parts.

info.title: UE G : Digital Design and Production (Autumn)
info.content:

• Case Studies: Rediscovery of elementary architectural concepts (mean of separation, mean of connection, mean of opening, etc) through the conscious use of adaptive tools and digital fabrication: one mean typology per group of students.
• Software: Introduction to 3D modeling (Rhinoceros), parametric and associative modeling (Grasshopper) and scripting (Visual Basic, Monkey).
• Geometry: Education on surface types (planarity, single curvature, double curvature).
• Methodology: Help in the discovery and digital fabrication basic concept application (cutting files preparation, generation of an automated nomenclature, minimization of the cutting times and material waste, etc).
• Fabrication: Training in conception and modeling for the use of laser cutter, waterjet cutter, 5 axis cnc router and thermoforming.
• Organization and planning for the efficient use of digital fabrication tool in the architectural project.
• Awareness raising to the basic principles of complexity management.
info.learning_outcomes:
• Introduction to the conception and the development of projects related to digital fabrication.
• Master the complementary use of 3D modeling and digital fabrication.
• Comprehension of implications and repercussions related to master the successive steps composing the digital chain: from conception to realization.
• Definition and fabrication of case studies: highlight the complementary process existing between the architectural language definition and the associated fabrication type.

info.title: UE H : Graphy I
info.content:
The language of pictures is composed by forms (point, line, surface, triangle, square), conventions (orthogonal projection, parallel and conical perspectives), techniques (drawing, colour, the range of image reproduction from typography to infography) as well as numerous themes common to different languages.

The UE Graphy I focuses on a small part of this global field: reproduction techniques of images. It is structured with several theoretical and historical contributions (image and perception, print, mark, memory, track, reproductibility and repetition) as well as pratical works where several techniques are experienced such as engraving, dry-point engraving, etched engraving, aquatint.
info.learning_outcomes: Communication and expression through the language of pictures, focusing on some image reproducing techniques based on an theme close to architecture (scenery for instance).

info.title: UE I : Analog-Digital-Virtual
info.content:
• Computing as a contemporary technology and aggregation of knowledge.
• The image out of graphical recording. Semantics and process.
• Heritage and genetical trails, defining the relationship between sensors capturing data within and beyond human perception.
info.learning_outcomes:
The representation of an object is concrete or abstract. It allows to "figure" a concept or to make visible the result of a calculation. The required codification of information in an abstract graphical transcription enables an easier explanation of a concept or of an assumption. It gives a better insight into the results of an observation or the data captured by a sensor. The scientific visualisation is also a research by itself, as a tool with which we can put forward hypothesises or simulate observations, in order to corroborate them, or on the contrary, to question them.

By means of a computer and several devices for numerical acquisition, the student will:

• model a space and geometrical objects, in a digital 3D environment, by integrating data from very diverse provenience (photography, video, 3D scans, and so on);
• plan the stage-set of an action in time and in numerical space;
• coordinate graphics and sounds of a single action;
• plan and realise a space and an animated sequence, with a clear and coherent conception of architecture and design;
• on the computer, model and draw scientific concepts or observations (for instance, anatomical, histological or psychological).

info.title: UE J : Territory and landscape
info.content: In the frame of the agglomeration plan for Lausanne and Morges (PALM), the TU J will address two peculiar topics of contemporary urbanism: the imperative of improving urban density and the ambition for dwelling in and belonging to a place with peculiar characters. The semester will be structured by two exercises: a large description about the agglomeration and the definition a design concept for a limited area. TU J 2011 will give us the opportunity to deepen our more general research upon the relevant unity of measuring and framing, in order to define an articulation between the territorial and the proximity scales.
info.learning_outcomes:
TU J introduces the architecture students to urban and territorial design, combining description and design concept:

• Description: adjusting the gaze (what and how to observe according to a certain degree of reduction) and the hand (how to formulate an adequate visual restitution, from the scale and graphic style points of view);
• Design: articulating spatial principles, programs and quantity;
• Description and design : relating them to a conceptual topic.

info.title: UE K : Environmental concepts and criteria
info.content:
The course will be organized around a façade design project, conducted by teams of students. Starting from an existing plan and from functional as well as performance objectives, students will be asked to re-think a building's envelope according to a sequence of design stages that will allow them to apply climate and sustainability concepts.

Topics that will be particularly emphasized are:

• Climate-responsive strategies.
• Energy-efficiency.
• Sustainable Façade Technologies.
• Lighting, Heating, Ventilation.
• Human Comfort.
info.learning_outcomes: This course will articulate itself around a design project with a focus on the climate-responsiveness and energy-efficiency of a building's envelope. It will introduce the theories behind a resource-efficient and sustainable structure and how the design of a façade can be conducted using performance goals. Students, working in teams, will thus be asked to explore different ways to effectively integrate both performance and climate considerations in their design exercise. Emphasis will be placed on energy and response to climate, on occupant comfort and health and on the adequate use of sustainable construction technologies.

info.title: Urban sociology
info.content:
• This course will be comprised of lectures combining theory, methodology, and case studies (the squatters' movement, the homeless, etc.), as well as practical exercises that will allow students to familiarize themselves with the sociological observation and analysis of urban phenomena (workshop sessions).

• With the help of classic and contemporary urban sociology theories, we will explore the various economic, political, social, and ethical processes that give shape and meaning to urban life. We will also look at the links between political ideals, urban and regional planning, and daily habits (routines, interaction in public places, sociability, etc.).

• Particular attention will be paid to the issue of diversity (rhythms, individual capacities and beliefs, cultural communities, etc.) and the practical and ethical problems it poses.
info.learning_outcomes:
The individualization and diversification of ways of living, the increase in mobilities, and the development of new forms of capitalism pose a great many challenges for urban development. Old ways of living together and of managing of differences - invented in the modern city - are running out of steam, giving rise to entirely new forms of suffering and injustice; henceforth, we must consider the possibility of an "inclusive city", meaning a city capable of overcoming processes of exclusion and segregation to offer just coexistence to individuals and communities in all their diversity.

In view of this, the goal of this course is to familiarize students with urban sociology and the tools it uses to describe and analyze issues facing the modern city, in an effort to renew critical and creative thinking about urban life and open up to new ways of thinking about the development of cities. At a time when the entire planet is urbanizing, such work seems critical.

• To analyse some globalization related issues: how are urban models circulating world-wide? Which are common characteristics of world cities? How are contemporary cities integrating the global scale in their production?

info.title: VLSI design II
info.content:
1. Introduction to VLSI CAD
Overview of CAD systems. Concept of automated design flow. Top-down and bottom-up design approaches. Practical aspects of using CAD systems in design.

2. Physical Design Automation
System-level partitioning and floor-planning. Logic partitioning. Module placement algorithms. Global and detailed routing algorithms. Design compaction methodologies. Performance-driven physical layout design.

3. Design Projects
The students will participate in a series of collaborative design exercises where each project group is assigned a task, to be completed in 3-4 weeks. The complexity of the design assignments will increase progressively, leading up to system-on-chip (SoC) realization by the end of the semester.

info.learning_outcomes: This course aims to familiarize the students with the design of very large-scale integrated (VLSI) circuits, using dedicated electronic design automation tools. Several functional blocks will be designed in practical exercises, and examples of system level integration will be shown.
